sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The island princesse. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1647. Date first performed: 1619-1621.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Pymero Christophero. Pedro Quisara Quisana Ruy Dias Armusia King of Bakam King of Syana Governor King of Tidore Soza Emanuel Captain Panura Keeper 1 Moor 2, Moor Citizen Soldier 1 Citizen 2 Citizen 3 Citizen Combined speech unknown speaker 1 Woman 2 Woman 3 Woman 1. Townsman 2. Townsman 3. Townsman 4. Townsman Messenger

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Pymero.
sp.l: Open the Ports, and see the watch relieved,
And let the guards be careful of their business
Their vigilant eyes fixed on these Islanders,
They are false and desperate people, when they find
The least occasion open to encouragement,
Cruel, and crafty souls, believe me Gentlemen,
Their late attempt, which is too fresh amongst us,
In which against all arms, and honesty,
The Governor of Ternata made surprise.
Of our confederate, the King of Tidore,
As for his recreation he was rowing
Between both Lands, bids us be wise and circumspect.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It was a mischief suddenly imagined,
And as soon done; that Governor is a fierce knave,
Unfaithful as he is fierce too, there is no trusting;
But I wonder much how such poor and base pleasures,
As tugging at an oar, or skill in steerage,
Should become Princes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Base breeding love base pleasure;
They take as much delight in a Baratto,
A little scurvy boat to row her tightly,
And have the art to turn and wind her nimbly,
Think is as noble too, though it be slavish,
And a dull labour that declines a Gentleman:
As we Portugalls, or the Spaniards do in riding,
In managing a great horse which is princely:
The French in Courtship, or the dancing English,
In carrying a fair presence.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He was strangely taken;
But where no faith is, there is no trust; he has paid for it
His sister yet the fair and great Quisara,
Has showed a noble mind, and much love in it
To her afflicted brother, and the nobler still it appears,
And seasons of more tenderness, because his ruin stiles her absolute
And his imprisonment adds to her profit.
Feeling all this, which makes all men admire her.
The warm beams of this fortune that fall on her,
Yet has she made diverse and noble treaties,
And propositions for her brothers freedom,
If wealth or honour --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Peace, peace, you are fooled sir;
Things of these natures have strange outsides Pedro,
And cunning shadows, set them far from us,
Draw them but near, they are gross, and they abuse us;
They that observe her close, shall find her nature,
Which I doubt mainly will not prove so excellent;
She is a Princess, and she must be fair,
That is the prerogative of being royal:
Let her want eyes and nose, she must be beauteous,
And she must know it too, and the use of it,
And people must believe it, they are damned else:
Why, all the neighbour Princes, are mad for her,

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Is she not fair then?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But her hopes are fairer,
And there is a haughty Master, the King of Bakan,
That lofty sir, that speaks far more and louder
In his own commendations than a Cannon:
He is strucken dumb with her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Beshrew me she is a sweet one.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And there is that hopeful man of Syana,
That sprightly fellow, he that is wise and temperate,
He is a lover too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Would I were worth her looking
For; by my life I hold her a complete one,
The very Sun I think, affects her sweetness,
And dares not as he does to all else, dye it
Into his tawny Livery.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: She dares not see him,
But keeps herself at distance from his kisses,
And wears her complexion in a case; let him but like it
A week or two, or three, she would look like a Lion;
But the main sport on it is, or rather wonder
The Governor of Ternata her mortal enemy,
He that has catched her brother King is struck too,
And is arrived under safe conduct also,
And hostages of worth delivered for him;
And he brought a letter from his prisoner,
Whether compelled, or willingly delivered
From the poor King, or what else dare be in it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: So it be honourable, anything , it is all one,
For I dare think she will do the best.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He has admittance, and solicits hourly,
Now if he have the trick --

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What trick?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: The true one,
To take her too, if he but skilled in bat-fowling,
And lime his bush right.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I will be hanged when that hits,
For it is not a compelled, or forced affection,
That must take her, I guess her stout and virtuous,
But where is your uncle sir, our valiant Captain,
The brave Ruy Dias all this while?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Aye marry,
He is amongst them too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A Lover.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay,
I know not that, but sure he stands in favour,
Or would stand stiffly, he is no Portugall else.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: The voice says in good favour, in the list too
Of the privy wooers, how cunningly of late
I have observed him, and how privately
He has stolen at all hours from us, and how readily
He has feigned a business to bid the Fort farewell
For five or six days, or a month together,
Sure there is something --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, yes, there is a thing in it,
A thing would make the best of us all dance after it;
A dainty thing; Lord how this uncle of mine
Has read to me, and rated me for wenching,
And told me in what desperate case it would leave me,
And how it would stew my bones.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You cared not for it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I'faith, not much, I ventured on still easily,
And took my chance, danger is a Soldiers honour;
But that this man, this herb of Grace, Ruy Dias,
This father of our faculties should slip thus,
For sure he is aferretting , that he
That would drink nothing to depress the spirit,
But milk and water, eat nothing but thin air
To make his blood obedient, that his youth
In spite of all his temperance, should tickle,
And have a love mange on him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It is in him sir
But honourable courtship, and becomes his rank too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: In me it were abominable Lechery, or would be,
For when our thoughts are on it, and miss their level,
We must hit something.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Well, it is a noble Gentleman,
And if he be a suitor, may he speed in it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Let him alone, our family never failed yet.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Our mad Lieutenant still merry Pyniero,
Thus would he do if the Surgeon were searching of him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Especially if a warm wench had shot him.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But hark Christophero; come hither Pedro;
When saw you our brave countryman Armusia?
He that is arrived here lately, and his gallants?
A goodly fellow, and a brave companion
Methinks he is, and no doubt truly valiant,
For he that dares come hither, dares fight anywhere .

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I saw him not of late, a sober Gentleman
I am sure he is, and no doubt bravely sprung,
And promises much nobleness.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I love him,
And by my troth would fain be inward with him;
Pray let us go seek him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: We will attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: By that time we shall hear the burst of business.

body.stage: Enter Ruy Dias, Quisara, Quisana, and Panura.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Aunt I much thank you for your courtesy,
And the fair liberty you still allow me,
Both of your house and service, though I be
A Princess, and by that Prerogative stand free
From the poor malice of opinion,
And no ways bound to render up my actions,
Because no power above me can examine me;
Yet my dear brother being still a prisoner,
And many wandering eyes upon my ways,
Being left alone a Sea-mark, it behoves me
To use a little caution, and be circumspect.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: You are wise and noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Often Aunt
I resort hither, and privately to see you,
It may be to converse with some I favour;
I would not have it known as oft, nor construed,
It stands not with my care.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: You speak most fairly,
For even our pure devotions are examined.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: So mad are men's minds now.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Or rather monstrous;
They are thick dreams, bread in fogs that know no fairness.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Madam the house is yours, I am yours, pray use me,
And at your service all I have lies prostrate;
My care shall ever be to yield ye honour,
And when your fame falls here, it is my fault Lady;
A poor and simple banquet I have provided,
Which if you please to honour with your presence --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I thank ye Aunt, I shall be with you instantly,
A few words with this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: I will leave ye,
And when you please retire, I will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Why, how now Captain, what afraid to speak to me?
A man of arms, and daunted with a Lady?
Commanders have the power to parley with Princes.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Madam, the favours you have still showered on me,
Which are so high above my means of merit,
So infinite, that naught can value them
But their own goodness, no eyes look up to them
But those that are of equal light, and lustre,
Strike me thus mute, you are my royal Mistress,
And all my services that aim at honour,
Take life from you, the Saint of my devotions;
Pardon my wish, it is a fair ambition,
And well becomes the man that honours you;
I would I were of worth, of something near you,
Of such a royal piece, a King I would be,
A mighty King that might command affection,
And bring a youth upon me might bewitch ye,
And you a sweet souled Christian.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Now you talk sir;
You Portugals, though you be rugged Soldiers,
Yet when you list to flatter, you are plain courtiers;
And could you wish me Christian brave Ruy Dias?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: At all the danger of my life great Lady,
At all my hopes, at all --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Pray ye stay a little,
To what end runs your wish?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: O glorious Lady,
That I might -- but I dare not speak.

sp.speaker: Quisar,
sp.l: I dare then,
That you might hope to marry me; nay blush not,
An honourable end needs no excuse;
And would you love me then?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: My soul not dearer.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Do some brave thing that may entice me that way,
Some thing of such a meritorious goodness,
Of such an unmatched nobleness, that I may know
You have a power beyond ours that preserves you,
It is not the person, nor the royal title,
Nor wealth, nor glory that I look upon,
That inward man I love that is lined with virtue,
That well deserving soul works out a favour;
I have many Princes suitors, many great ones,
Yet above these I love you, you are valiant,
An active man, able to build a fortune;
I do not say I dote, nor mean to marry,
Only the hope is something may be done,
That may compel my faith, and ask my freedom,
And leave opinion fair.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Command dear Lady,
And let the danger be as deep as hell,
As direful to attempt --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: You are too sudden,
I must be ruled by you, find out a fortune
Wisely and handsomely, examine time,
And court occasion that she may be ready;
A thousand uses for your forward spirit
Ye may find daily, be sure ye take a good one,
A brave and worthy one that may advance ye,
Forced smiles reward poor dangers; you are a Soldier,
I would not talk so else, and I love a Soldier,
And that that speaks him true, and great, his valour;
Yet for all these which are but women's follies,
You may do what you please, I shall still know ye,
And though ye wear no sword.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Excellent Lady,
When I grow so cold, and disgrace my nation,
That from their hardy nurses suck adventures,
It were fit I wore a Tombstone; you have read to me
The story of your favour, if I mistake it,
Or grow a tenant in the study of it,
A great correction Lady --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Let us to the banquet,
And have some merrier talk, and then to Court,
Where I give audience to my general Suitors;
Pray heaven my woman's wit hold; there brave Captain,
You may perchance meet something that may startle ye;
I will say no more, come be not sad --
I love ye.

body.stage: Enter Pyniero, Armusia Soza, Christophero, and Emanuel.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You are welcome gentlemen, most worthy welcome,
And know there is nothing in our power may serve ye,
But you may freely challenge.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Sir we thank ye,
And rest your servants too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye are worthy Portugals,
You show the bravery of your minds and spirits;
The nature of our country too, that brings forth
Stirring, unwearied souls to seek adventures;
Minds never satisfied with search of honour
Where time is, and the sun gives light, brave countrymen,
Our names are known, new worlds disclose their riches,
Their beauties, and their prides to our embraces;
And we the first of nations find these wonders.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: These noble thoughts sir, have enticed us forward,
And minds unapt for ease to see these miracles,
In which we find report a poor relater;
We are arrived among the blessed Islands,
Where every wind that rises blows perfumes,
And every breath of air is like an Incense:
The treasure of the Sun dwells here, each tree
As if it envied the old Paradise,
Strives to bring forth immortal fruit; the spices
Renewing nature, though not deifying,
And when that falls by time, scorning the earth,
But as we dreamt, forever so preserve us:
Nothing we see, but breeds an admiration;
The very rivers as we float along,
Throw up their pearls, and curl their heads to court us;
The bowels of the earth swell with the births
Of thousand unknown gems, and thousand riches;
Nothing that bears a life, but brings a treasure;
The people they show brave too, civil mannered,
Proportioned like the Masters of great minds,
The women which I wonder at --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye speak well.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Of delicate aspects, fair, clearly beauteous,
And to that admiration, sweet and courteous.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And is not that a good thing? brave Armusia
You never saw the Court before?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No certain,
But that I see a wonder too, all excellent,
The Government exact.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ye shall see anon,
That that will make ye start indeed, such beauties,
Such riches, and such form.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: We are fire already;
The wealthy Magazine of nature sure
Inhabits here.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: These sure are all Islanders.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, and great Princes too, and lusty lovers.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: They are goodly persons, what might he be seignior
That bears so proud a state?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: King of Bakam,
A fellow that farts terror,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: He looks highly,
Sure he was begot on the top of a steeple.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It may well be,
For you shall hear him ring anon.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That is Syana,
And a brave tempered fellow, and more valiant.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: What rugged face is that?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That is the great Governor,
The man surprised our friend, I told ye of him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He has dangerous eyes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: A perilous thief, and subtle.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: And to that subtlety a heart of Iron.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yet the young Lady makes it melt.

sp.speaker: Ar,
sp.l: They start all,
And thunder in the eyes.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Away ye poor ones,
Am I in competition with such bubbles?
My virtue, and my name ranked with such trifles?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ye speak loud.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Young-man, I will speak louder;
Can any man but I, deserve her favour,
You petty Princes?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He will put them all in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Thou proud mad thing be not so full of glory,
So full of vanity.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How? I contemn thee,
And that fort-keeping fellow,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How the dog looks,
The bandog Governor?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ha, why?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Away thing,
And keep your rank with those that fit your loyalty;
Call out the Princess.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Dost thou know me bladder,
Thou insolent imposthume?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I despise thee;

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Art thou acquainted with my nature baby?
Let my revenge for injuries? darest thou hold me
So far behind thy file, I cannot reach thee?
What canst thou merit?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Merit? I am above it;
I am equal with all honours, all achievements,
And what is great and worthy; the best doer
I keep at my command, fortune is my servant,
It is in my power now to despise such wretches,
To look upon ye slightly, and neglect ye,
And but she deigns at some hours to remember ye,
And people have bestowed some titles on ye,
I should forget your names --

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Mercy of me;
What a blown fool has self affection
Made of this fellow? did not the Queen your mother,
Long for bellows, and bagpipes when she was great with ye,
She brought forth such a windy birth?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It is ten to one
She eat a Drum, and was delivered of alarum,
Or else he was swaddled in an old sail when he was young.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He swells too mainly with his meditations;
Faith talk a little handsomer, ride softly
That we may be able to hold way with ye, we are Princes,
But those are but poor things to you; talk wiser,
It will well become your mightiness; talk less,
That men may think ye can do more.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Talk truth,
That men may think ye are honest, and believe ye,
Or talk yourself asleep, for I am weary of you.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Why? I can talk and do.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: That would do excellent.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And tell you, only I deserve the Princess,
And make good only I, if you dare, you sir,
Or your Syanas Prince.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Here is a storm toward,
Methinks it sings already, to him Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Here lies my proof.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I will be short with ye,
For these long arguments I was never good at.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How white the boaster looks?

body.stage: Enter Ruy Dias, Quisara, Quisana, Panura.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I see he lacks faith.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: For shame forbear great Princes, rule your angers,
You violate the freedom of this place,
The state and royalty --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He is well contented
It seems, and so I have done.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Is this she seignior?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is the Princess sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: She is sweet and goodly,
An admirable form, they have cause to jostle.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Ye wrong me and my court, ye forward Princes;
Comes your love wrapped in violence to seek us?
Is it fit though you be great, my presence should be
Stained, and polluted with your bloody rages?
My privacies affrighted with your swords?
He that loves me, loves my command; be tempered,
Or be no more what ye profess, my Servants.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are calm as peace.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What command she carries?
And what a sparkling Majesty flies from her?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Is it ye love to do? ye shall find danger,
And danger that shall start your resolutions,
But not this way; it is not contention,
Who loves me to my face best, or who can flatter most
Can carry me, he that deserves my favour,
And will enjoy what I bring, love and Majesty,
Must win me with his worth; must travel for me;
Must put his hasty rage off, and put on
A well confirmed, temperate, and true valour.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: But show the way.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: And will, and then show you
A will to tread the way, I will say ye are worthy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: What task now
Will she turn them to? these hot youths,
I fear will find a cooling card, I read in her eyes
Something that has some swing must fly amongst them ;
By this hand I love her a little now.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: It is not unknown to you
I had a royal brother, now miserable,
And Prisoner to that man; if I were ambitious,
Gaped for that glory was never born with me,
There they should lie as miseries upon him:
If I were covetous, and my heart set
On riches, and those base effects that follow
On pleasures uncontrolled, or safe revenges,
There he should die, his death would give me all these;
For then stood I up absolute to do all;
Yet all these flattering shows of dignity,
These golden dreams of greatness cannot force
To forget nature and my fair affection.
Therefore that man that would be known my lover,
Must be known his redeemer, and must bring him
Either alive or dead to my embraces,
For even his bones I scorn shall feele such slavery,
Or seek another Mistress, it will be hard
To do this, wondrous hard, a great adventure,
Fit for a spirit of an equal greatness;
But being done, the reward is worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: How they stand gaping all?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Ruy Dias cold?
Not fly like fire into it? may be you doubt me,
He that shall do this is my husband Prince;
By the bright heavens he is, by whose justice
I openly proclaim it; if I lie,
Or seek to set you on with subtlety,
Let that meet with me, and reward my falsehood.
No stirring yet, no start into a bravery?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Madam, it may be, but being a main danger,
Your Grace must give me leave to look about me,
And take a little time, the cause will ask it,
Great acts require great counsels.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Take your pleasure,
I fear the Portugall.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I will raise an Army
That shall bring back his Island fort and all,
And fix it here.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: How long will this be doing?
You should have begun in your Grandfathers days.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What may be,
And what my power can promise noblest Lady,
My will I am sure stands fair.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Fair be your fortune,
Few promises are best, and fair performance.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: These cannot do,
Their power and arts are weak ones.
It is in my will, I have this King your brother,
He is my prisoner, I accept your prisoner,
And bless the fair occasion that achieved him:
I love ye, and I honour ye, but speak
Whether alive or dead he shall be rendered,
And see how readily, how in an instant,
Quick as your wishes Lady --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: No, I scorn ye,
You and your courtesy; I hate your love sir;
And ere I would so basely win his liberty,
I would study to forget he was my brother;
By force he was taken; he that shall enjoy me,
Shall fetch him back by force, or never know me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: As I live, a rare wench.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: She has a noble spirit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: By force?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Yes sir by force, and make you glad too
To let him go.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: How? you may look nobler on me,
And think me no such boy; by force he must not,
For your love much may be.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Put up your passion,
And pack ye home, I say, by force, and suddenly.
He lies there till he rots else, although I love him
Most tenderly and dearly, as a brother,
And out of these respects would joy to see him;
Yet to receive him as thy courtesy,
With all the honour thou couldst add unto him
From his hands that most hate him, I had rather
Though no condition were propounded for him,
See him far sunk in the earth, and there forget him.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Your hopes are gelt good Governor.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: A rare woman.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Lady,
I will pull this pride, I will quench this bravery,
And turn your glorious scorn to tears and howlings;
I will proud Princess; this neglect of me
Shall make thy brother King most miserable;
Shall turn him into curses against thy cruelty:
For where before I used him like a King,
And did those Royal Offices unto him,
Now he shall lie a sad lump in a dungeon,
Laden with chains and fetters, colds and hunger,
Darkness and lingering death for his companions;
And let me see who dare attempt his rescue,
What desperate fool; look toward it; farewell,
And when thou knowest him thus, lament thy follies,
Nay I will make thee kneel to take my offer:
Once more farewell, and put thy trust in puppets.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: If none dare undertake it, I will live a mourner.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You cannot want.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You must not.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: It is most dangerous,
And wise men would proceed with care and counsel.
Yet some way would I knew --
Walk with me Gentlemen --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How do you like her spirit?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: It is a clear one,
Clod with no dirty stuff, she is all pure honour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The bravest wench I ever looked upon,
And of the strongest parts, she is most fair,
Yet her mind such a mirror --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: What an action
Would this be to put forward one, what a glory,
And what an everlasting wealth to end it?
Methinks my soul is strangely raised.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: To step into it,
Just while they think, and ere they have determined
To bring the King off.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Things have been done as dangerous.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And prospered best when they were least considered.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Bless me my hopes,
And you my friends assist me.
None but our companions.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: You deal wisely,
And if we shrink the name of slaves die with us.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Stay not for second thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am determined;
And though I lose, it shall be sung, I was valiant,
And my brave offer shall be turned to story,
Worthy the Princess tongue. A boat that is all
That is unprovided, and habits like to merchants,
The rest we will counsel as we go.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Away then,
Fortune looks fair on those, make haste to win her.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: I have kept many a man, and many a great one,
Yet I confess, I never saw before
A man of such a sufferance; he lies now
Where I would not lay my dog, for sure it would kill him.
Where neither light or comfort can come near him;
Nor air, nor earth that is wholesome; it grieves me
To see a mighty King with all his glory,
Sunk of the sudden to the bottom of a dungeon.
Whether should we descend that are poor Rascals
If we had our deserts?

sp.speaker: 1 Mo.
sp.l: It is a strange wonder,
Load him with Irons, oppress him with contempts,
Which are the Governors commands, give him nothing,
Or so little, to sustain life, it is next nothing;
They stir not him, he smiles upon his miseries,
And bears them with such strength as if his nature
Had been nursed up, and fostered with calamities.
He gives no ill words, curses, nor repines not,
Blames nothing, hopes in nothing we can hear of;
And in the midst of all these frights, fears nothing.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: He fears not, for even when I shake for him,
As many times my pity will compel me,
When other souls that bear not half his burthen,
Shrink in their powers, and burst with their oppressions;
Then will he sing, woo his afflictions,
And court them in sad aires, as if he would wed them.
That is more than we have heard yet, we are only
Appointed for his guard, but not so near him,
If we could hear that wonder --

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Many times
I fear the Governor should come to know it;
For his voice so affects me, so delights me,
That when I find his hour, I have Music ready,
And it stirs me infinitely, be but still and private,
And you may chance to hear.

body.stage: King appeares loden with chaines, his head, arms only above

sp.l: We will not stir sir;
This is a sudden change, but who dares blame it.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Now hark and melt, for I am sure I shall;
Stand silent, what stubborn weight of chains --
Yet he looks temperately.
His eyes not sunk, and his complexion firm still,
No wildness, no distempered touch upon him.
How constantly he smiles, and how undaunted?
With what a Majesty he heaves his head up?

sp.speaker: Ke.
sp.l: Now mark, I know he will sing; do not disturb him.
Your allowance from the Governor, would it were more sir,
Or in my power to make it handsomer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do not transgress thy charge, I take his bounty,
And fortune, whilst I bear a mind contented,
Not leavened with the glory I am fallen from,
Nor hang upon vain hopes, that may corrupt me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Thou art my slave, and I appear above thee.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: The Governor himself.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What, at your banquet?
And in such state, and with such change of service?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Nature is no glutton sir, a little serves her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: This diet is wholesome then.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I beg no better.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: A calm contented mind, give him less next;
These full meals will oppress his health, his Grace
Is of a tender, and pure constitution,
And such repletions --

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Mock, mock, it moves not me sir,
Thy mirths, as do thy mischiefs fly behind me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ye carry it handsomely, but tell me patience,
Do not you curse the brave and royal Lady
Your gracious sister? do not you damn her pity,
Damn twenty times a day, and damn it seriously?
Do not you swear aloud too, cry and kick?
The very soul sweat in thee with the agony
Of her contempt of me? couldst not thou eat her
For being so injurious to thy fortune,
Thy fair and happy fortune? couldst not thou wish her
A Bastard, or a whore, fame might proclaim her
Black ugly fame, or that thou hadst had no sister?
Spitting the general name out, and the nature;
Blaspheming heaven for making such a mischief;
For giving power to pride, and will to woman?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No Tyrant, no, I bless and love her for it;
And though her scorn of thee, had laid up for me
As many plagues as the corrupted-air breeds,
As many mischiefs as the hours have minutes,
As many forms of death, as doubt can figure;
Yet I should love her more still, and more honour her;
All thou canst lay upon me, cannot bend me,
No not the stroke of death, that I despise too:
For if fear could possess me, thou hadst won me;
As little from this hour I prize thy flatteries,
And less than those thy prayers, though thou wouldst kneel to me;
And if she be not Mistress of this nature,
She is none of mine, no kin, and I contemn her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Are you so valiant sir?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Yes, and so fortunate;
For he that holds my constancy still conquers;
Hadst thou preserved me as a noble enemy,
And as at first, made my restraint seem to me
But only as the shadow of captivity,
I had still spoke thee noble, still declared thee
A valiant, great, and worthy man, still loved thee,
And still preferred thy fair love to my sister;
But to compel this from me with a misery,
A most inhumane, and unhandsome slavery --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You will relent for all this talk I fear not,
And put your wits a-work again.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You are cozened;
Or if I were so weak to be wrought to it,
So fearful to give way to so much poverty,
How I should curse her heart if she consented.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You shall write and entreat or --

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do thy utmost,
And even in all thy tortures I will laugh at thee,
I will think thee no more valiant, but a villain;
Nothing thou hast done brave, but like a thief,
Achieved by craft, and kept by cruelty;
Nothing thou canst deserve, thou art unhonest;
Nor no way live to build a name, thou art barbarous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Down with him low enough, there let him murmur,
And see his diet be so light and little,
He grow not thus high hearted on it, I will cool ye,
And make ye cry for mercy, and be ready
To work my ends, and willingly; and your sister taken down ,
Your scornful, cruel sister shall repent too,
And sue to me for grace.
Give him no liberty,
But let his bands be doubled, his ease lessened;
Nothing his heart desires, but vex and torture him:
Let him not sleep, nothing that is dear to nature
Let him enjoy; yet take heed that he die not;
Keep him as near death, and as willing to embrace it,
But see he arrive not at it; I will humble him,
And her stout heart that stands on such defiance;
And let me see her champions that dare venture
Her high and mighty wooers, keep your guards close,
And as you love your lives be diligent,
And what I charge, observe.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We shall be dutiful.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I will pull your courage King and all your bravery.
Most certain he is resolved nothing can stir him;
For if he had but any part about him
Gave way to fear or hope, he durst not talk thus,
And do thus stoutly too, as willingly,
And quietly he sunk down to his sorrows,
As some men to their sleeps.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Yes, and sleeps with them;
So little he regards them, there is the wonder,
And often soundly sleeps, would I durst pity him,
Or would it were in my will, but we are servants,
And tied unto command.
I wish him better,
But much I fear he has found his tomb already,
We must observe our guards.
He cannot last long,
And when he is dead, he is free.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: That is the most cruelty,
That we must keep him living.
That is as he please;
For that man that resolves, needs no Physician.

body.stage: Enter Armusia, Soza, Emanuel like merchants, Arm'd underneath.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Our prosperous passage was an omen to us,
A lucky and a fair omen.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We believe it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The sea and wind strove who should most befriend us,
And as they favoured our design and loved us,
So lead us forth -- where lies the boat that brought us?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Safe lodged within the Reeds, close by the Castle,
That no eye can suspect, nor thought come near it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But where have you been, brave sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have broke the Ice boys:
I have begun the game, fair fortune guide it,
Suspectless have I travelled all the town through,
And in this Merchants shape won much acquaintance,
Surveyed each strength and place that may befriend us.
Viewed all his Magazines, got perfect knowledge
Of where the prison is, and what power guards it.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: These will be strong attempts.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Courage is strong:
What we began with policy, my dear friends,
Let us end with manly force; there is no retiring,
Unless it be with shame.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Shame his that hopes it

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Better a few, and clearer fame will follow us,
However, lose or win, and speak our memories,
Then if we led our Armies; things done thus,
And of this noble weight, will style us worthies.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Direct, and we have done, bring us to execute,
And if we flinch, or fail --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am sure ye dare not.
Then further know, and let no ear be near us
That may be false.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Speak boldly on, we are honest;
Our lives and fortunes yours.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hard by the place then
Where all his treasure lies, his arms, his women,
Close by the prison too where he keeps the King,
I have hired a lodging, as a trading merchant,
A Cellar to that too, to stow my wares in,
The very wall of which, joins to his store-house.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: What of all this?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye are dull, if ye apprehend not:
Into that Cellar, elected friends, I have conveyed
And unsuspected too that will do it;
That that will make all shake, and smoke too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My thoughts have not been idle, nor my practice:
The fire I brought here with me shall do something,
Shall burst into material flames and bright ones,
That all the Island shall stand wondering at it,
As if they had been stricken with a Comet:
Powder is ready, and enough to work it,
The match is left afire, all, all hushed, and locked close,
No man suspecting what I am but Merchant:
An hour hence, my brave friends, look for the fury,
The fire to light us to our honoured purpose,
For by that time it will take.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: What are our duties?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: When all are full of fear and fright, the Governor
Out of his wits, the to see flames so imperious,
Ready to turn to ashes all he worships,
And all the people there to stop these ruins,
No man regarding any private office;
Then fly we to the prison suddenly,
Here is one has found the way, and dares direct us.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then to our swords and good hearts,
I long for it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Certain we shall not find much opposition,
But what is must be forced.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: It is bravely cast sir,
And surely too I hope.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If the fire fail not,
And powder hold his nature, some must presently
Upon the first cry of the amazed people,
(For nothing will be marked then, but the misery)
Be ready with the boat upon an instant,
And then all is right and fair.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Bless us dear fortune.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let us be worthy of it in our courage,
And fortune must befriend us, come all sever,
But keep still within sight, when the flame rises
Let us meet, and either do, or die.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: So be it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No Captain, for those troops we need them not,
The Town is strong enough to stand their furies;
I would see them come, and offer to do something.
They are high in words.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It is safer sir than doing.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Dost think they dare attempt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: May be by treaty
But sure by force they will not prove so forward.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No faith, I warrant thee, they know me well enough,
And know they have no child in hand to play with:
They know my nature too, I have bit some of them,
And to the bones, they have reason to remember me,
It makes me laugh to think how glorious
The fools are in their promises and how pregnant
Their wits and powers are to bring things to pass;
Am I not grown lean with loss of sleep and care
To prevent these threatenings, Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You look well sir:
Upon my conscience you are not like to sicken
Upon any such conceit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I hope I shall not:
Well would I had this wench, for I must have her,
She must be mine; and there is another charge Captain;
What betwixt love and brawling I got nothing,
All goes in maintenance --
Hark what was that,
That noise there? it went with a violence.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Some old wall belike sir,
That had no neighbour help to hold it up,
Is fallen suddenly.

sp.speaker: Gov;
sp.l: I must discard these Rascals,
That are not able to maintain their buildings,
They blur the beauty of the Town.
Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I hear another tune, good Captain,
It comes on fresher still, it is loud and fearful,
Look up into the Town, how bright the air shows;
Upon my life some sudden fire.
The bell too?
I hear the noise more clear

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Suddenly taken in a Merchant's house sir,
Fearful and high it blazes; help good people.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Pox on their paper-houses, how they smother,
They light like candles, how the roar still rises?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Your Magazine is a fire sir, help, help suddenly,
The Castle too is in danger, in much danger,
All will be lost, get the people presently,
And all that are your guard, and all help, all hands sir,
Your wealth, your strength, is burnt else, the town perished;
The Castle now begins to flame.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: My soul shakes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Merchants house next joining? shame light on him,
That ever such a neighbour, such a villain --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Raise all the garrison, and bring them up.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: And beat the people forward -- O I have lost all
In one house, all my hopes: good worthy Citizens
Follow me all, and all your powers give to me,
I will reward you all. O cursed fortune --
The flames more violent: arise still, help, help Citizens,
Freedom and wealth to him that helps: follow, O follow.
Fling wine, or anything, I will see it recompensed.
Buckets, more Buckets; fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Let it flame on, a comely light it gives up
To our discovery.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Hark, what a merry cry
These hounds make? forward fairly,
We are not seen in the mist, we are Not noted. Away,
Away. Now if we lose our fortune --

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Up soldiers, up, and deal like men.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: More water, more water, all is consumed else.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: All is gone, unless you undertake it straight, your
Wealth too, that must preserve, and pay your labour bravely.
Up, up, away.

body.stage: Ex.Cap. and Cit. Then, Enter Armusia and his company breaking open a doore.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: So, thou art open, keep the way clear
Behind still. Now for the place.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: It is here sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sure this is it.
Force ope the door -- A miserable creature!
Yet by his manly face --

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why stare ye on me?
You cannot put on faces to affright me:
In death I am a King still, and contemn ye:
Where is that Governor? methinks his man-hood
Should be well pleased to see my Tragedy,
And come to bath his stern eyes in my sorrows;
I dare him to the fight, bring his scorns with him,
And all his rugged threats: here is a throat, soldiers;
Come, see who can strike deepest.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Break the Chain there.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come, talk of no more Governors,
He has other business sir, put your legs forward,
And gather up your courage like a man,
We will carry off your head else: we are friends,
And come to give your sorrows ease.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: On bravely;
Delays may lose again,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The Guard.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Upon them.

sp.speaker: Ar
sp.l: Make speedy, and sure work.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: They fly.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Up with him, and to the Boat; stand fast, now be speedy,
When this heat is past, we will sing our History.
Away, like thoughts, sudden as desires, friends;
Now sacred chance be ours.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Pray when we have done sir.
What is the fire allayed?
It is out, it is out,
Or past the worst, I never did so stoutly
I will assure you neighbours since I was a man:
I have been burnt at both ends like a squib:
I lived two hours in the fire, it was a hideous matter;
But when men of understanding come about it,
Men that judge of things, my wife gave me over,
And took her leave a hundred times, I bore up still,
And tossed the Buckets boys.
We are all mere Martins.
I heard a voice at latter end of the hurry,
Or else I dreamt I heard it, that said treason.
It is like enough, it might cry murder too , for there was
Many without a joint, but what is that to us: Let us home
And fright our wives, for we look like Devils.
Here come some of them to fright us.

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: Mine is alive neighbour -- O sweet honey husband.
Thou liest I think abominably, and thou hadst been
In my place, thou wouldst have stunk at both ends.
Get me some drink, give me whole tuns of drink,
Whole cisterns; for I have four dozen of fine firebrands
In my belly, I have more smoke in my mouth, than would
Blot a hundred herrings.

sp.speaker: 2 Wo.
sp.l: Art thou come safe again?

sp.speaker: 3 Wo.
sp.l: I pray you what became of my man, is he in a well?
At hearts ease in a Well, is very well neighbour;
We left him drinking of a new dozen of Buckets;
Thy husband is happy, he was through roasted,
And now he is basting off himself at all points:
The Clarke and he are cooling their pericraniums;
Body O me neighbours there is fire in my codpiece.

sp.speaker: 1 Wo.
sp.l: Bless my husband.
Blow it out wife -- blow, blow, the gable end at the store-house.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.l: Some water, water, water.
Peace, it is but a sparkle;
Raise not the Town again, it will be a great hindrance,
I am glad it is out, if it had taken in my hayloft?
What frights are these, marry heaven bless thy modicum.

sp.speaker: 3 Wo.
sp.l: But is he drowned outright, pray put me out of
Fear neighbour.
Thou wouldst have it so, but after a hundred fires
More, he will live to see thee burnt for brewing musty
Liquor.
Come let us go neighbour.
For I would very fain turn down this liquor;
Come, come, I fry like a burnt marry-bone:
Women get you afore, and draw upon us;
Run wenches run, and let your taps run with ye;
Run as the fire were in your tails, cry ale, ale.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Away let us nourish the poor wretches.
We will Rally up the rest of the burnt Regiment.

body.stage: Enter Governor, Captaine, Souldier, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: The fire is quenched Captain, but the mischief hangs still;
The King is redeemed and gone too; a trick, a damned one:
O I am overtaken poorly, tamely.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Where were the guard that waited upon the prison?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Most of them slain, yet some scaped sir, and they deliver,
They saw a little boat ready to receive him,
And those redeemed him, making such haste and fighting;
Fighting beyond the force of men.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am lost Captain,
And all the world will laugh at this, and scorn me:
Count me a heavy sleepy fool, a coward,
A coward past recovery, a confirmed coward,
One without carriage, or common sense.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: He is gone sir,
And put to sea amain, past our recovery,
Not a Boat ready to pursue; if there were any,
The people stand amazed so at their valour,
And the sudden fright of fire, none knows to execute.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: O , I could tear my limbs,and knock my boys brains
Against every post I meet; fooled with a fire?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It was a crafty trick.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No, I was lazy,
Confident sluggish lazy, had I but met them,
And changed a dozen blows, I had forgiven them,
By both these hands held up, and by that brightness
That gilds the world with light, by all our worships,
The hidden ebbs and flows of the blue Ocean,
I will not rest; no mirth shall dwell upon me,
Wine touch my mouth, nor anything refresh me,
Till I be wholly quit of this dishonour:
Make ready my Barratos instantly,
And what I shall intend --

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: We are your servants.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Never tell me, you never cared to win me,
Never for my sake to attempt a deed,
Might draw me to a thought you sought my favour:
If not for love of me, for love of arms sir,
For that cause you profess, for love of honour,
Of which you style yourself the mighty Master,
You might have stepped out nobly, and made an offer,
As if you had intended something excellent,
Put on a forward face.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Dear Lady hold me --

sp.speaker: Quisar,
sp.l: I hold ye, as I find ye, a faint servant.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: By -- I dare do --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: In a Ladies chamber
I dare believe ye, there is no mortal danger:
Give me the man that dares do, to deserve that:
I thought you Portugalls had been rare wonders,
Men of those haughty courages and credits,
That all things were confined within your promises,
The Lords of fate and fortune I believed ye,
But well I see I am deceived Ruy Dias,
And blame too late my much belief.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I am ashamed, Lady,
I was so dull, so stupid to your offer:
Now you have once more schooled me, I am right,
And something shall be thought on suddenly,
And put in act as soon, some preparation --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: And give it out?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Yes, Lady, and so great too;
In which, the noise of all my Countrymen --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Those will do well, for they are all approved ones,
And though he be restored alive.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I have ye.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: For then we are both servants.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I conceive ye,
Good Madam give me leave to turn my fancies.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: Do, and make all things fit,and then I will visit you.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Myself, the cozen, and the Garrison,
The neighbours of the out-Isles of our nation,
Syana's strength, for I can humour him:
And proud Bekamus, I shall deceive his glory.
What ringing sound of joy is this? whence comes it?
May be the Princes are in sport.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Where are ye?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Now Pyniero, what is the haste you seek me?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Do you know this sign sir?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Do you know this emblem?
Your nose is boared.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Boared? what is that?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You are topped sir:
The King is come home again, the King.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: The devil?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay sure he came in gods name home:
He is returned sir.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.l: And all this joy ye hear --

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Who durst attempt him?
The Princes are all here.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: They are worthy Princes,
They are special Princes, all they love by ounces.
Believe it sir, it is done, and done most bravely and easily.
What fortune have ye lost sir?
What justice have ye now unto this Lady?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How stands your claim?
That ever man should be fooled so,
When he should do and prosper; stand protesting,
Kissing the hand, and farting for a favour,
When he should be about his business sweating;
She bid you go, and picked you out on purpose,
To make yourself a fortune by, a Lady, a Lady, and a lusty one,
A lovely, that now you may go look, she pointed ye,
Knowing you were a man of worth and merit,
And bid you fly, you have made a fair flight on it ,
You have caught a goose.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: How dare you thus molest me?
It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Hark how the general joy rings!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Have you your hearing left? is not that drunk too?
For if you had been sober, you had been wise sure.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Done? who dares do?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It seems an honest fellow,
That has ended his Market before you be up.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: The shame on it is a stranger too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It is no shame,
He took her at her word, and tied the bargain,
Dealt like a man indeed, stood not demurring,
But clapped close to the cause, as he will do to the Lady:
He is a fellow of that speed and handsomeness,
He will get her with child too, ere you shall come to know him,
Is it not brave, a gentleman scarce landed,
Scarce eating of the air here, not acquainted,
No circumstance of love depending on him,
Nor no command to show him, must start forth,
At the first sight to --

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Like an Oyster:
She neither taking view, nor value of him,
Unto such deeds as these -- Pox on these,
These wise delayings --
They make men cowards.
You are undone as a man would undo an egg,
A hundred shames about ye.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Can it be possible,
A stranger that I have not known, not seen yet,
A man I never graced; O Captain, Captain,
What shall I do? I am betrayed by fortune,
It cannot be, it must not be.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It is Lady,
And by my faith a handsome Gentleman;
It is his poor Scholars prize.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Must I be given
Unto a man I never saw, never spoke with,
I know not of what Nation?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Is a Portugall,
And of as good a pitch he will be given to you Lady,
For he is given much to handsome flesh.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: O Ruy Dias,
This was your sloth, your sloth, your sloth Ruy Dias.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Your love sloth, Uncle do you find it now?
You should have done at first, and faithfully:
And then the the other had lied ready for ye;
Madam, the general joy comes.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: We must meet it -- but with what comfort?

body.stage: Enter Citizens carrying boughes, boyes singing after 'em Then King, Armusia, Soza, Emanuell; The Princes and traine following.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: O my dear brother what a joy runs through me,
To see you safe again, yourself, and mighty,
What a blessed day is this?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Rise up fair sister,
I am not welcome till you have embraced me.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A general gladness sir flies through the City,
And mirth possesses all to see your Grace arrive,
Thus happily arrived again, and fairly;
It was a brave venture whosoever put for it,
A high and noble one, worthy much honour;
And had it failed, we had not failed great sir,
And in short time too to have forced the Governor,
In spite of all his threats.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: And all his subtleties to set you free,
With all his heart and will too.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I know ye love me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This had been good with something done before it,
Something set off to beautify it, now it sounds empty like
A Barbers basin pox there is no metal in it , no noble marrow.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I have an army sir, but that the Governor,
The foolish fellow was a little provident,
And wise in letting slip no time, became him too,
That would have scoured him else, and all his confines;
That would have rung him such a peal --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes backward,
To make dogs howl, I know thee to a farthing,
Thy army is good for hawks, there is
Nothing but sheeps hearts in it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I have done nothing sir, therefore
I think it convenient I say little what I purposed,
And what my love intended.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I like your modesty,
And thank ye royal friends, I know it grieved ye
To know my misery; but this man Princes,
I must thank heartily indeed and truly,
For this man saw me in it, and redeemed me:
He looked upon me sinking, and then caught me.
This sister this, this all man, this all valour,
This pious man.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: My countenance, it shames me,
One scarce arrived, not hardened yet, not
Read in dangers and great deeds, sea-sick, not seasoned --
O I have buoyed myself.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: This noble bulwark,
This lance and honour of our age and Kingdom;
This that I never can reward, nor hope
To be once worthy of the name of friend to,
This, this man from the bowels of my sorrows
Has new begot my name, and once more made me:
O sister, if there may be thanks for this,
Or anything near recompense invented.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You are too noble sir, there is reward
Above my action too by millions:
A recompense so rich and glorious,
I durst not dream it mine, but that it was promised;
But that it was propounded, sworn and sealed
Before the face of heaven, I durst not hope it,
For nothing in the life of man, or merit,
It is so truly great, can else embrace it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O speak it, speak it, bless mine ears to hear it,
Make me a happy man to know it may be,
For still methinks I am a prisoner,
And feele no liberty before I find it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Then know it is your sister, she is mine sir,
I claim her by her own word, and her honour;
It was her open promise to that man
That durst redeem ye; Beauty set me on,
And fortune crowns me fair, if she receive me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Receive ye sir -- why sister -- ha -- so backward,
Stand as you knew me not, nor what he has ventured
My dearest sister.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good sir pardon me,
There is a blushing modesty becomes her,
That holds her back; women are nice to woo sir;
I would not have her forced, give her fair liberty;
For things compelled and frighted of soft natures,
Turn into fears, and fly from their own wishes.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Look on my Quisara such another,
O all ye powers, so excellent in nature,
In honour so abundant.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I confess sir,
Confess my word is past too, he has purchased;
Yet good sir give me leave to think, but time
To be acquainted with his worth and person;
To make me fit to know it; we are both strangers,
And how we should believe so suddenly,
Or come to fasten our affections --
Alas, love has his complements.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Be sudden
And certain in your way, no woman's doubles,
Nor coy delays, you are his, and so assure it,
Or cast from me and my remembrance ever;
Respect your word, I know you will, come sister,
Let us see what welcome you can give a prisoner,
And what fair looks a friend -- O my most noble
Princes, no discontents, but all be lusty,
He that frowns this day is an open enemy:
Thus in my arms my dear.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You make me blush sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And now lead on --
Our whole Court crowned with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Madam, despair not, something shall be done yet,
And suddenly and wisely.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: O Ruy Dias.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well he is a brave fellow, and he has deserved her richly,
And you have had your hands full I dare swear Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: We have done something sir, if it hit right.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: The woman has no eyes else, nor no honesty,
So much I think.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come, let us go bounce amongst them,
To the Kings health, and my brave country-man's.
My uncle looks as though he were sick of the
Worms friends.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Mine uncle haunts me up and down, looks melancholy,
Wondrous proof melancholy, sometimes swears,
Then whistles, starts, cries, and groans, as if he had the Bots.
As to say truth, I think he has little better,
And would fain speak; bids me good morrow at midnight,
And good night when it is noon, has something hovers
About his brains, that would fain find an issue,
But cannot out, or dares not: still he follows;
How he looks still, and how he beats about,
Like an old Dog at a dead sent? Aye marry,
There was a sigh would a set a ship asailing :
These winds of love and honour blow at all ends.
Now speak if it be thy will: good morrow Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is a new salute:
Sure he has forgot me: this is purblind Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: My Nephew?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes sir, if I be not changed.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I would fain speak with you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I would fain have ye sir,
For to that end I stay.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You know I love ye,
And I have loved you long, my dear Pyniero,
Bred and supplied you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Whither walks this Preamble?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You may remember, though I am but your Uncle,
I sure had a fathers care, a fathers tenderness.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Sure he would wrap me into something now suddenly,
He doubts my nature in, for mine is honest,
He winds about me so.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A fathers diligence.
My private benefits, I have forgot sir,
But those you might lay claim to as my follower;
Yet some men would remember --

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I do daily.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: The place which I have put ye in, which is no weak one,
Next to myself you stand in all employments,
Your counsels, cares, assignments with me equal,
So is my study still to plant your person;
These are small testimonies I have not forgot ye,
Nor would not be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Sure you cannot.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: O Pyniero --

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Sir, what hangs upon you,
What heavy weight oppresses ye, ye have lost,
(I must confess, in those that understand ye)
Some little of your credit, but time will cure that;
The best may slip sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: O my best Nephew --

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: It may be ye fear her too, that disturbs ye,
That she may fall herself, or be forced from ye.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: She is ever true, but I undone forever .
O that Armusia, that new thing, that stranger,
That flag stuck up to rob me of mine honour;
That murdering chain shot at me from my Country;
That goodly plague that I must court to kill me.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Now it comes flowing from him, I feared this,
Knew, he that durst be idle, durst be ill too,
Has he not done a brave thing?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I must confess it nephew, must allow it,
But that brave thing has undone me, has sunk me,
Has trod me like a name in sand to nothing,
Hangs betwixt hope and me, and threatens my ruin:
And if he rise and blaze, farewell my fortune;
And when that is set, where is thy advancement Cozen?
That were a friend, that were a noble kinsman,
That would consider these; that man were grateful;
And he that durst do something here durst love me.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: You say true, it is worth consideration,
Your reasons are of weight, and mark me Uncle,
For I will be sudden, and to the purpose with you.
Say this Armusia then wert taken off,
As it may be easily done
How stands the woman?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: She is mine forever ;
For she contemns his deed and him.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Pox on him,
Or if the single pox be not sufficient,
The hogs, the dogs, and devils pox possess him:
I'Faith this Armusia stumbles me, he is a brave fellow;
And if he could be spared Uncle --

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I must perish:
Had he set up at any rest but this,
Done anything but what concerned my credit,
The everlasting losing of my worth. --

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I understand you now, who set you on too;
I had a reasonable good opinion of the devil
Till this hour; and I see he is a knave indeed,
An arrant stinking knave, for now I smell him;
I will see what may be done then, you shall know
You have a kinsman, but no villain Uncle,
Nor no betrayer of fair fame, I scorn it;
I love and honour virtue; I must have
Access unto the Lady to know her mind too,
A good word from her mouth you know may stir me;
A Ladies look at setting on --

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You say well;
Here Cozen, here is a Letter ready for you,
And you shall see how nobly she will receive you,
And with what care direct.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Farewell then Uncle,
After I have talked with her, I am your servant,
To make you honest if I can -- else hate you.
Pray ye no more complements, my head is busy, heaven bless me;
What a malicious soul does this man carry?
And to what scurvy things this love converts us?
What stinking things, and how sweetly they become us?
Murther is a moral virtue with these Lovers,
A special piece of Divinity I take it:
I may be mad, or violently drunk,
Which is a whelp of that litter; or I may be covetous,
And learn to murther men's estates, that is base too;
Or proud, but that is a Paradise to this;
Or envious, and sit eating of myself
At others fortunes; I may lie, and damnably,
Beyond the patience of an honest hearer;
Cousin, Cut purses, sit in the stocks for apples.
But when I am a lover, Lord have mercy,
These are poor pelting sins, or rather plagues,
Love and Ambition draw the devil's Coach.
How now! who are these? O my great Ladies followers,
Her riddle-founders, and her fortune-tellers,
Her readers of her love-lectures, her inflamers:
These doors I must pass through, I hope they are wide.
Good day to your beauties, how they take it to them?
As if they were fair indeed.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: Good morrow to you sir.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: That is the old Hen, the brood-bird? how she busses?
How like an Inventory of Lechery she looks?
Many a good piece of iniquity
Has past her hands, I warrant her -- I beseech you,
Is the fair Princess stirring?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes marry is she sir,
But somewhat private: have you a business with her?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Yes forsooth have I, and a serious business.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: May not we know?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Yes, when you can keep counsel.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How prettily he looks? he is a soldier sure,
His rudeness sits so handsomely upon him.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: A good blunt gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Yes marry am I:
Yet for a push or two at sharp, if it please you --

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My honest friend, you know not who you speak to:
This is the Princess Aunt.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I like her the better
If she were her Mother, (Lady) or her grandmother,
I am not so bashful but I can buckle with her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Of what size is your business?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Of the long sixteens,
And will make way I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How fine he talks?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay in troth I talk but coarsely, Lady,
But I hold it comfortable for the understanding:
How fain they would draw me into ribaldry?
These wenches that live easily, live high,
And love these broad discourses, as they love possets;
These dry delights serve for preparatives.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why do you look so on me?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I am guessing
By the cast of your face, what the property of your place should be,
For I presume you turn a key sweet beauty,
And you another gravity, under the Princess,
And by my -- I warrant ye good places,
Comely commodious feats.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Prithee let him talk still,
For methinks he talks handsomely.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And truly
As near as my understanding shall enable me
You look as if you kept my Ladies secrets:
Nay do not laugh, for I mean honestly,
How these young things tattle, when they get a toy by the end?
And how their hearts go pit a pat and look for it?
Would it not dance too, if it had a Fiddle?
Your gravity I guess, to take the Petitions,
And hear the lingering suits in love disposed,
Their sighs and sorrows in their proper place,
You keep the aim office.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Prithee suffer him,
For as I live he is a pretty fellow.
I love to hear sometimes what men think of us:
And thus delivered freely, it is no malice:
Proceed good honest man.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I will, good Madam.
According to men's states and dignities,
Monies and movables, you rate their dreams,
And cast the Nativity of their desires,
If he reward well, all he thinks is prosperous:
And if he promise place, his dreams are Oracles;
Your ancient practic Art too in these discoveries,
Who loves at such a length, who a span farther,
And who draws home, yield you no little profit,
For these ye milk by circumstance.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Ye are cunning.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: And as they Oil ye, and advance your spindle,
So you draw out the lines of love, your doors too,
The doors of destiny, that men must pass through;
These are fair places.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He knows all.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Your trap doors,
To pop fools in it, that have no providence,
Your little wickets, to work wise men, like wires through at,
And draw their states and bodies into Cobwebs,
Your Postern doors, to catch those that are cautelous,
And would not have the worlds eye find their knaveries:
Your doors of danger, some men hate a pleasure,
Unless that maybe full of fears; your hope doors,
And those are fine commodities, where fools pay
For every new encouragement, a new custom;
You have your doors of honour, and of pleasure;
But those are for great Princes, glorious vanities,
That travel to be famous through diseases;
There be the doors of poverty and death too:
But these you do the best you can to dam up,
For then your gain goes out.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: This is a rare lecture.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Read to them that understand.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Beshrew me,
I dare not venture on ye, ye cut too keen sir.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: We thank you sir for your good mirth
You are a good Companion.
Here comes the Princess now, attend your business.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Is there no remedy? no hopes can help me?
No wit to set me free? who is there ho?

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Troubled? her looks are almost wild:
What ails the Princess?
I know nothing she wants.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Who is that there with you?
O Seignior Piniero? you are most welcome:
How does your noble uncle?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Sad as you are Madam:
But he commends his service, and this Letter.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Go off, attend within -- Fair sir, I thank ye,
Pray be no stranger, for indeed you are welcome;
For your own vertues welcome.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: We are mistaken,
This is some brave fellow sure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am sure he is a bold fellow:
But if she hold him so, we must believe it.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Do you know of this fair sir?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I guess it Madam,
And whither it intends: I had not brought it else.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: It is a business of no common reckoning.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: The handsomer for him that goes about it;
Slight actions are rewarded with slight thanks:
Give me a matter of some weight to wade in.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: And can you love your Uncle so directly,
So seriously, and so full, to undertake this?
Can there be such a faith?

sp.speaker: Pyn:
sp.l: Dare you say Aye to it,
And set me on? it is no matter for my Uncle,
Or what I owe to him, dare you but wish it.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I would fain --

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Have it done; say but so Lady.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Conceive it so.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I will, it is that I am bound too:
Your will that must command me, and your pleasure,
The fair aspects of those eyes, that must direct me:
I am no Uncles agent, I am mine own, Lady;
I scorn my able youth should plough for others,
Or my ambition serve for pay; I aim,
Although I never hit, as high as any man,
And the reward I reach at shall be equal,
And what love spurs me on to, this desire,
Makes me forget an honest man, a brave man,
A valiant, and a virtuous man, my country-man, Armusia,
The delight of all the Minions,
Is love of you, doting upon your beauty, the admiration of your excellence;
Make me but servant to the poorest smile,
Or the least grace you have bestowed on others,
And see how suddenly I will work your safety,
And set your thoughts at peace; I am no flatterer,
To promise infinitely, and out-dream dangers;
To lie a bed, and swear men into Fevers,
Like some of your trim suitors; when I promise,
The light is not more constant to the world,
Than I am to my word -- She turns for millions.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I have not seen a braver confirmed courage.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: For a tun of Crowns she turns: she is a woman,
And much I fear a worse than I expected.
You are the object Lady, you are the eye
In which all excellence appears, all wonder,
From which all hearts take fire, all hands their valour:
And when he stands disputing, when you bid him,
Or but thinks of his estate, Father, Mother,
Friends, Wife, and Children,
Is a fool, and I scorn him,
And be but to make clean his sword: coward
Men have forgot their fealty to beauty.
Had I the place in your affections,
My most unworthy uncle is fit to fall from,
Lived in those blessed eyes, and read the stories
Of everlasting pleasures figured there,
I would find out your commands before you thought them,
And bring them to you done, ere you dream it of them.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: I admire his boldness.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: This, or anything;
Your brothers death, mine uncles, any man's,
No state that stands secure, if you frown on it.
Look on my youth, I bring no blastings to you,
The first flower of my strength, my faith.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: No more sir;
I am too willing to believe, rest satisfied;
If you dare do for me, I shall be thankful:
You are a handsome gentleman, a fair one,
My servant if you please; I seal it thus sir.
No more, till you deserve more.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I am rewarded:
This woman is cunning, but she is bloody too;
Although she pulls her Talons in,she is mischievous;
Formed like the face of heaven, clear and transparent;
I must pretend still, bear them both in hopes,
For fear some bloody slave thrust in indeed,
Fashioned and fleshed to what they wish: well uncle,
What will become of this, and what dishonour
Follow this fatal shaft, if shot, let time tell,
I can but only fear, and cross to cross it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why are you thus sad? what can grieve or vex you
That have the pleasures of the world, the profits,
The honour, and the loves at your disposes?
Why should a man that wants nothing, want his quiet?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I want what beggars are above me in, content:
I want the grace I have merited,
The favour, the due respect.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Does not the King allow it?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes and all honours else, all I can ask,
That he has power to give; but from his sister,
The scornful cruelty, forgive me beauty,
That I transgress from her that should look on me,
That should a little smile upon my service,
And foster my deserts for her own faiths sake;
That should at least acknowledge me, speak to me.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: And you go whining up and down for this sir,
Lamenting and disputing of your grievances;
Sighing and sobbing like a sullen Schoolboy,
And cursing good-wife fortune for this favour.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Do what you should do,
What a man would do in this case, a wise man,
An understanding man that knows a woman;
Knows her and all her tricks, her scorns and all her trifles:
Go to her and take her in your arms and shake her,
Take her and toss her like a bar.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But be sure you pitch her upon a feather-bed,
Shake her between a pair of sheets sir,
There shake these sullen fits out of her, spare her not there,
There you may break her will, and bruise no bone sir.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Go to her.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: That is the way.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: And tell her and boldly,
And do not mince the matter, nor mock yourself,
With being too indulgent to her pride:
Let her hear roundly from ye, what ye are,
And what ye have deserved, and what she must be.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And be not put off like a common fellow,
With the Princess would be private,
Or that she has taken physic, and admits none,
I would talk to her anywhere .

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It makes me smile.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now you look handsomely:
Had I a wench to win, I would so flutter her,
They love a man that crushes them to verjuice;
A woman held at hard meat is your spaniel.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Pray take our counsel sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I shall do something,
But not your way, it shows too boisterous,
For my affections are as fair and gentle,
As her they serve.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why, how now friend?
Why do you rob me of the company
I love so dearly sir, I have been seeking you;
For when I want you. I want all my pleasure:
Why sad? thus sad still man; I will not have it;
I must not see the face I love thus shadowed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: If it please your Grace, methinks it ill becomes him,
A soldier should be jovial, high and lusty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He shall be so, come, come, I know your reason,
It shall be none to cross you, ye shall have her,
Take my word, (it is a Kings word) ye shall have her,
She shall be yours or nothing, pray be merry.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Your grace has given me cause, I shall be sir,
And ever your poor servant.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Me myself sir,
My better self, I shall find time, and suddenly,
To gratify your loves too gentlemen,
And make you know how much I stand bound to you:
Nay it is not worth your thanks, no further complement;
Will you go with me friend?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I beseech your grace,
Spare me an hour or two, I shall wait on you,
Some little private business with myself sir,
For such a time.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will hinder no devotion,
For I know you are regular, I will take you gentlemen,
Because he shall have nothing to disturb him,
I shall look for your friend.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I dare not fail sir:
What shall I do to make her know my misery,
To make her sensible? This is her woman,
I have a toy come to me suddenly,
It may work for the best, she can but scorn me,
And lower than I am I cannot tumble,
I will try what ere my fate be -- Good even fair one,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It is the brave stranger -- A good night to you sir.
Now by my Ladies hand a goodly gentleman!
How happy shall she be in such a husband?
Would I were so provided too.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Good pretty one,
Shall I keep you company for an hour or two?
I want employment for this evening.
I am an honest man.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I dare believe ye:
Or if ye were not sir, that is no great matter,
We take men's promises, would ye stay with me sir?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: So it please you; pray let us be better acquainted,
I know you are the Princess gentlewoman,
And wait upon her near.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It is like I do so.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: And may befriend a man, do him fair courtesies,
If he have business your way.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I understand ye.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: So kind an office, that you may bind a gentleman
Hereafter to be yours, and your way too,
And ye may bless the hour you did this benefit,
Sweet handsome faces should have courteous minds,
And ready faculties.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Tell me your business,
Yet if I think it be to her, yourself sir,
For I know what you are, and what we hold ye,
And in what grace ye stand, without a second
For that but darkens, you would do it better,
The Princess must be pleased with your accesses,
I am sure I should.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I want a Courtiers boldness,
And am yet but a stranger, I would fain speak with her:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It is very late, and upon her hour of sleep sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Pray ye wear this, and believe my meaning civil,
My business of that fair respect and carriage:
This for our more acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How close he kisses?
And how sensible the passings of his lips are?
I must do it, if I were to be hanged now, and I will do it,
He may do as much for me, that is all I aim at,
And come what will of it, life or death, I will do it,
For ten such kisses more, and it were high treason.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I would be private with her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So you shall,
It is not worth thanks else, you must dispatch quick.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Suddenly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And I must leave you in my chamber sir,
Where you must lock yourself that none may see you,
It is close to her, you cannot miss the entrance,
When she comes down to bed.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I understand ye, and once more thank ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thank me but thus.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If I fail thee --
Come close then.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: It is late good Aunt, to bed, I am even unready,
My! woman will not be long away.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: I would have you a little merrier first,
Let me sit by ye, and read or discourse
Something that ye fancy, or take my instrument.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: No, no I thank you,
I shall sleep without these, I wrong your age Aunt
To make ye wait thus, pray let me entreat ye,
Tomorrow I will see ye, I know you are sleepy,
And rest will be a welcome guest, you shall not,
Indeed you shall not stay; O here is my woman,
Good night, good night, and good rest Aunt attend you.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Sleep dwell upon your eyes, and fair dreams court ye.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Come, where have you been wench? make me unready;
I slept but ill last night.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You will sleep the better
I hope tonight Madam.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: A little rest contents me,
Thou lovest thy bed Panura.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am not in love Lady,
Nor seldom dream of devils, I sleep soundly.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I will swear thou dost, thy husband would not take it so well
If thou wert married wench.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Let him take Madam
The way to waken me, I am no dormouse.
