Husbands have larum bells, if they but
Ring once.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Thou art a merry wench.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I shall live the longer.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Prithee fetch my book.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am glad of that.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I will read a while before I sleep.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: And if Ruy Dias meet you and be importunate,
He may come in.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I have a better fare for you,
Now least in sight play I.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Why should I love him?
Why should I dote upon a man deserves not,
Nor has no will to work it? who is there wench?
What are you? or whence come you?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Ye may know me,
I bring not such amazement noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Who let you in?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: My restless love that serves ye.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: This is an impudence I have not heard of,
A rudeness that becomes a thief or ruffian;
Nor shall my brothers love protect this boldness,
You build so strongly on, my rooms are sanctuaries,
And with that reverence they that seek my favours,
And humble fears, shall render their approaches.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Mine are no less.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I am Mistress of myself sir.
And will be so, I will not be thus visited;
These fears and dangers thrust into my privacy,
Stand further off, I will cry out else.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: O dear Lady!

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I see dishonour in your eyes.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: There is none:
By all that beauty they are innocent;
Pray ye tremble not, you have no cause.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I will die first;
Before you have your will, be torn in pieces;
The little strength I have left me to resist you,
The gods will give me more, before I am forced
To that I hate, or suffer --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: You wrong my duty.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: So base a violation of my liberty?
I know you are bent unnobly; I will take to me
The spirit of man, borrow his boldness,
And force my woman's fears into a madness,
And ere you arrive at what you aim at --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Lady,
If there be in you any woman's pity?
And if your fears have not proclaimed me monstrous?
Look on me and believe me; is this violence?
Is it to fall thus prostrate to your beauty
A ruffians boldness? is humility a rudeness?
The griefs and sorrows that grow here an impudence?
These forcings, and these fears I bring along with me,
These impudent abuses offered ye;
And thus high has your brothers favour blown me:
Alas dear Lady of my life, I came not
With any purpose rough, or desperate,
With any thought that was not smooth and gentle
As your fair hand, with any doubt or danger,
Far be it from my heart to fright your quiet;
A heavy curse light on it when I intend it.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Now I dare hear you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If I had been mischievous,
As then I must be mad; or were a monster,
If any such base thought had harboured here,
Or violence that became not man,
You have a thousand bulwarks to assure you,
The holy powers bear shields to defend chastity;
Your honour and your vertues are such armours;
Your clear thoughts such defences; if you misdoubt still,
And yet retain a fear I am not honest,
Come with impure thoughts to this place;
Take this, and sheath it here; be your own safety;
Be wise, and rid your fears, and let me perish;
How willing shall I sleep to satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: No, I believe now, you speak worthily;
What came you then for?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: To complain, me beauty,
But modesty.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Of your fierce cruelty,
For though I die, I will not blame the doer:
Humbly to tell your grace, ye had forgot me:
A little to have touched at, not accused,
For that I dare not do, your scorns, pray pardon me
And be not angry, that I use the liberty
To urge that word, a little to have showed you
What I have been, and what done to deserve ye,
If anything that love commands may reach ye,
To have remembered ye, but I am unworthy,
And to that misery falls all my fortunes,
To have told ye, and by my life ye may believe me,
That I am honest, and will only marry
You, or your memory; pray be not angry.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I thank you sir, and let me tell you seriously,
Ye have taken now the right way to befriend ye,
And to beget a fair and clear opinion,
Yet to try your obedience --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I stand ready Lady,
Without presuming to ask anything .

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Or at this time to hope for further favour;
Or to remember services, or smiles;
Dangers you have past through, and rewards due to them;
Loves or despairs, but leaving all to me:
Quit this place presently.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I shall obey ye.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Who is this?
What art thou?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Thou art no more I am sure: O it is Ruy Dias;
How high he looks, and harsh?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Is there not door enough,
You take such elbow room?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If I take it, I will carry it.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Does this become you Princess?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: The Captain is jealous,
Jealous of that he never durst deserve yet;
Go freely, go I will give thee leave.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Your leave sir?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Yes my leave sir, I will not be troubled neither,
Nor shall my heart ache, or my head be jealous,
Nor strange suspicious thoughts reign in my memory;
Go on, and do thy worst, I will smile at thee;
I kiss your fair hand first, then farewell Captain.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: What a pure soul inherits here? what innocence?
Sure I was blind when I first loved this fellow,
And long to live in that fog still: how he blusters!

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Am I your property? or those your flatteries,
The banquets that ye bid me to, the trust
I build my goodly hopes on?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Be more temperate.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Are these the shows of your respect and favour?
What did he here? what language had he with ye?
Did ye invite? could ye stay no longer?
Is he so gracious in your eye?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: You are too forward.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Why at these private hours?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: You are too saucy,
Too impudent to task me with those errors:
Do ye know what I am sir, and my prerogative?
Though you be a thing I have called by the name of friend,
I never taught you to dispose my liberty;
How durst you touch mine honour? blot my meanings?
And name an action, and of mine but noble?
Thou poor unworthy thing, how have I graced thee?
How have I nourished thee, and raised thee hourly?
Are these the gratitudes you bring Ruy Dias?
The thanks? the services? I am fairly paid;
Was it not enough I saw thou wert a Coward,
And shadowed thee? no noble sparkle in thee?
Daily provoked thee, and still found thee coward?
Raised noble causes for thee, strangers started at;
Yet still, still, still a Coward, ever Coward;
And with those taints, dost thou upbraid my vertues?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I was to blame
Lady.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: So blindly bold to touch at my behaviour?
Durst thou but look amiss at my allowance?
If thou hadst been a brave fellow, thou hadst had some licence,
Some liberty I might have then allowed thee
For thy good face, some scope to have argued with me;
But being nothing but a sound, a shape,
The mere sign of a Soldier -- of a Lover,
The dregs and drafty part, disgrace and jealousy,
I scorn thee, and contemn thee.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Dearest Lady,
If I have been too free --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Thou hast been too foolish,
And go on still,I will study to forget thee,
I would I could, and yet I pity thee.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I am not worth it, if I were, that is misery,
The next door is but death, I must aim at it.

body.stage: Enter King, and Governor like a Moore Priest.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: So far and truly you have discovered to me
The former currents of my life and fortune,
That I am bound to acknowledge ye most holy,
And certainly to credit your predictions
Of what are yet to come.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am no liar,
It is strange I should, and live so near a neighbour;
But these are not my ends.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Pray ye sit good father,
Certain a reverend man, and most religious.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Aye , that belief is well now, and let me work then,
I will make ye curse religion ere I leave ye;
I have lived a long time son, a mewed up man,
Sequestered by the special hand of heaven
From the worlds vanities, bid farewell to follies,
And shook hands with all heats of youth and pleasures,
As in a dream these twenty years I have slumbered,
Many a cold moon have I in meditation,
And searching out the hidden wills of heaven,
Lain shaking under, many a burning Sun
Has feared my body, and boiled up my blood,
Feebled my knees, and stamped a Meagerness
Upon my figure, all to find out knowledge,
Which I have now attained to , thanks to heaven,
All for my countries good too, and many a vision,
Many a mystic vision have I seen son,
And many a sight from heaven which has been terrible,
Wherein the goods and evils of these Islands
Were lively shadowed; many a charge I have had too,
Still as the time grew ripe to reveal these,
To travel and discover, now I am come son,
The hour is now appointed,
My tongue is touched, and now I speak.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do holy man, I will hear ye.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Beware these Portugals, I say beware them,
These smooth faced strangers, have an eyes upon them .
The cause is now the God's, hear, and believe King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do hear, but before I give rash credit,
Or hang too light on belief, which is a sin father;
Know I have found them gentle, faithful, valiant,
And am in my particular, bound to them,
I mean to some for my most strange deliverance.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: O Son, the future aims of men, observe me,
Above their present actions, and their glory,
Are to be looked at: the stars show many turnings,
If you could see, mark but with my eyes pupil;
These men came hither as my vision tells me,
Poor, weather beaten, almost lost, starved, feebled,
Their vessels like themselves, most miserable;
Made a long suit for traffic, and for comfort,
To vent their children's toys, cure their diseases:
They had their suit, they landed, and to the rate
Grew rich and powerful, sucked the fat, and freedom
Of this most blessed Isle, taught her to tremble,
Witness the Castle here, the Citadel,
They have clapped upon the neck of your Tidore,
This happy town, till that she knew these strangers,
To check her when she is jolly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: They have so indeed father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Take heed, take heed, I find your fair delivery,
Though you be pleased to glorify that fortune,
And think these strangers Gods, take heed I say,
I find it but a handsome preparation,
A fair faced Prologue to a further mischief:
Mark but the end good King, the pin he shoots at
That was the man delivered ye; the mirror,
Your Sister is his due; what is she, your heir sir?
And what is he a kin then to the Kingdom?
But heirs are not ambitious, who then suffers?
What reverence shall the Gods have? and what justice
The miserable people? what shall they do?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He points at truth directly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Think of these son:
The person, nor the manner I mislike not
Of your preserver, nor the whole man together,
Were he but seasoned in the faith we are,
In our devotions learned.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You say right father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To change our worships now, and our Religion?
To be traitor to our God?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have well advised me,
And I will seriously consider father,
In the mean time you shall have your fair access
Unto my sister, advise her to your purpose,
And let me still know how the Gods determine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I will, but my main end is to advise
The destruction of you all, a general ruin,
And then I am revenged, let the Gods whistle.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Indeed, I am right glad ye were not greedy,
And sudden in performing what I willed you,
Upon the person of Armusia,
I was afraid, for I well knew your valour,
And love to me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It was not a fair thing uncle,
It showed not handsome, carried no man in it.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I must confess it was ill, and I abhor it,
Only this good has risen from this evil;
I have tried your honesty, and find proof,
A constancy that will not be corrupted,
And I much honour it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This Bell sounds better.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: My anger now, and that disgrace I have suffered,
Shall be more manly vented, and wiped off,
And my sick honour cured the right and straight way;
My Sword is in my hand now nephew, my cause upon it,
And man to man, one valour to another,
My hope to his.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why? this like Ruy Dias?
This carries something of some substance in it;
Some mettle and some man, this sounds a gentleman;
And now methinks, ye utter what becomes ye;
To kill men scurvily, it is such a dog trick,
Such a rat catchers occupation --

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: It is no better,
But Pyniero now --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now I do bravely.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: The difference of our states flung by forgotten,
The full opinion I have won in service,
And such respects that may not show us equal,
Laid handsomely aside, only our fortunes,
And single manhoods --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: In a service sir,
Of this most noble nature, all I am,
If I had ten lives more, those and my fortunes
Are ready for ye, I had thought ye had forsworn fighting,
Or banished those brave thoughts were wont to wait upon you
I am glad to see them called home again.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: They are nephew,
And thou shall see what fire they carry in them,
Here, you guess what this means.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, very well sir,
A portion of Scripture that puzzles many an interpreter.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: As soon as you can find him --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That will not be long uncle,
And on my conscience he will be ready as quickly.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I make no doubt good Nephew, carry it so
If you can possible that we may fight.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, you shall fight assure yourself.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Pray ye hear me
In some such place where it may be possible
The Princess may behold us.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I conceive ye,
Upon the sand behind the Castle sir,
A place remote enough, and there be windows
Out of her lodgings too, or I am mistaken.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: You are in the right, if ye can work that handsomely --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Let me alone, and pray be you prepared
Some three hours hence.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I will not fail.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Get you home,
And if you have any things to dispose of,
Or a few light prayers
That may befriend you, run them over quickly,
I warrant, I will bring him on.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Farewell Nephew,
And when we meet again --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Aye, aye , fight handsomely;
Take a good draught or two of wine to settle ye,
It is an excellent armour for an ill conscience Uncle;
I am glad to see, this man's conversion,
I was afraid fair honour had been bedridden,
Or beaten out of the Island, soldiers and good ones,
Intended such base courses? he will fight now;
And I believe too bravely; I have seen him
Curry a fellows carcass handsomely:
And in the head of a troop stand as if he had been rooted there,
Dealing large doles of death; what a rascal was I
I did not see his will drawn?
What does she here?
If there be any mischief toward, a woman makes one still;
Now what new business is for me?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I was sending for ye,
But since we have met so fair,
You have saved that labour; I must entreat you sir --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Anything Madam,
Your wills are my commands.

sp.speaker: Qusar.
sp.l: You are nobly courteous;
Upon my better thoughts Seignior Pyniero,
And my more peaceable considerations.
Which now I find the richer ornaments;
I would desire you to attempt no farther
Against the person of the noble stranger,
In truth I am ashamed of my share in it;
Nor be incited further by your uncle,
I see it will sit ill upon your person;
I have considered, and it will show ugly
Carried at best, a most unheard of cruelty;
Good sir desist --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You speak now like a woman,
And wondrous well this tenderness becomes ye;
But this you must remember -- your command
Was laid on with a kiss, and seriously
It must be taken off the same way Madam,
Or I stand bound still.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: That shall not endanger ye,
Look ye fair sir, thus I take off that duty.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: By the mass it was soft and sweet,
Some bloods would bound now,
And run a tilt; do not you think bright beauty,
You have done me in this kiss a mighty favour,
And that I stand bound by virtue of this honour,
To do what ever you command me?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I think sir,
From me these are unusual courtesies,
And ought to be respected so; there are some,
And men of no mean rank, would hold themselves
Not poorly blessed to taste of such a bounty.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I know there are that would do many unjust things
For such a kiss, and yet I hold this modest;
All villainies body and soul dispense with,
For such a provocation, kill their kindred,
Demolish the fair credits of their Parents;
Those kisses I am not acquainted with, most certain Madam
The appurtenance of this kiss would not provoke me
To do a mischief, it is the devils own dance,
To be kissed into cruelty.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I am glad you make that use sir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I am gladder
That you made me believe you were cruel,
For by this hand I know I am so honest,
However I deceived ye, it was high time too,
Some common slave might have been set upon it else,
That willingly I would not kill a dog
That could but fetch and carry for a woman,
She must be a good woman made me kick him,
And that will be hard to find, to kill a man,
If you will give me leave to get another,
Or any she that played the best game at it.
And fore a woman's anger prefer her fancy.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I take it in you well.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I thank ye Lady,
And I shall study to confirm it.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Do sir,
For this time, and this present cause I allow it,
Most holy sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Bless ye my royal daughter,
And in you, bless this Island heaven.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Good Aunt,
What think ye of this man?

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Sure he is a wise man,
And a religious, he tells us things have happened
So many years ago almost forgotten,
As readily, as if they were done this hour.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Does he not meet with your sharpe tongue?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He tells me Madam,
Marriage, and mouldy cheese will make me tamer.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: A stubborn keeper, and worse fare,
An open stable, and cold care,
Will tame a Jade, may be your share.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Byrlady, a sharp prophet, when this proves good
I will bequeath you a skin to make ye a hood.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Lady I would talk with you.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Do reverend sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: And for you good, for that that must concern ye,
And give ear wisely to me.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I shall father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are a Princess of that excellence,
Sweetness, and grace, that Angel-like fair feature,
Nay, do not blush, I do not flatter you,
Nor do I dote in telling this, I am amazed Lady,
And as I think the gods bestowed these on ye,
The gods that love ye.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I confess their bounty.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Apply it then to their use, to their honour,
To them, and to their service give this sweetness;
They have an instant great use of your goodness;
You are a Saint esteemed here for your beauty,
And may a longing heart --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I seek no fealty,
Nor will I blemish that heaven has sealed on me,
I know my worth, indeed the Portugals
I have at those commands, and their last services,
Nay, even their lives, so much I think my handsomeness,
That what I shall enjoin --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Use it discreetly,
For I perceive ye understand me rightly,
For here the gods regard your help, and suddenly;
The Portugals like sharpe thorns (mark me Lady)
Stick in our sides, like razors, wound religion,
Draw deep, they wound, till the life blood follows,
Our gods they spurn at, and their worships scorn,
A mighty hand they bear upon our government,
These are the men your miracle must work on,
Your heavenly form, either to root them out,
Which as you may endeavour will be easy,
Remember whose great cause you have to execute,
To nip their memory, that may not spring more,
Or fairly bring them home to our devotions,
Which will be blessed, and for which, you sainted,
But cannot be, and they go; let me bustle.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Go up with me,
Where we will converse more privately;
I will show ye shortly how I hold their temper;
And in what chain their souls.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Keep fast that hold still,
And either bring that chain, and those bound in it,
And link it to our gods, and their fair worships,
Or daughter pinch their hearts a pieces with it,
I will wait upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Come reverend father.
Wait you below.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: If this prophet were a young thing,
I should suspect him now, he cleaves so close to her;
These holy coats are long, and hide in iniquities.

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Away, away fool, a poor wretch,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: These poor ones
Warm but their stomachs once --

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: Come in, thou art foolish.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am sorry sir my fortune is so stubborn,
To court my sword against my countryman,
I love my nation well, and where I find
A Portugall of noble name and virtue,
I am his humble servant.Seignior Pyniero,
Your person, nor your uncles am I angry with,
You are both fair Gentlemen in my opinion,
And I protest, I had rather use my sword
In your defences, than against your safeties;
It is methinks, a strange dearth of enemies,
When we seek foes among ourselves.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You are injured,
And you must make the best of it now, and readiest --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: You see I am ready in the place, and armed
To his desire that called me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye speak honestly,
And I could wish ye had met on terms more friendly.
But it cannot now be so.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Turn sir, and see.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I have kept my word with ye uncle,
The Gentleman is ready.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Ye are welcome.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Bid those fools welcome that affect your courtesy,
I come not to use complement, ye have wronged me,
And ye shall feele proud man ere I part from ye,
The effects of that, if fortune do not fool me;
Thy life is mine, and no hope shall redeem thee.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: That is a proud word,
More than your faith can justify.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Sure they will fight.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: She is there, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Let them alone, let them kill one another,
These are the main posts, if they fall, the buildings
Will tumble quickly.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: How temperate Armusia?
No more, be quiet yet.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am not bloody,
Nor do not feele such mortal malice in me,
But since we cannot both enjoy the Princess,
I am resolved to fight.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Fight home Armusia,
For if thou faintest, or fallest --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Do ye make all vantages?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Always; unto thy life I will not spare thee,
Nor look not for thy mercy.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am armed then.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Stand still I charge ye nephew, as ye honour me.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: And good Emanuel -- not --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye speak fitly,
For we had not stood idle else.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But since you will have it so --

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I weight ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Aye marry this looks handsomely,
This is warm work.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Both fall if it be thy will.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: My Uncle dead?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Stand still, or my swords in --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now brave Ruy Dias,
Now where is your confidence, your prayers? quickly
Your own spite has condemned ye.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Hold Armusia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Most happy Lady.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Hold and let him rise,
Spare him for me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A long life may he enjoy Lady.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What have you done? it is better they had all perished.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Peace father, I work for the best; Armusia,
Be in the garden an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I shall Madam.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now as I live a Gentleman at all inches,
So brave a mingled temper saw I never.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why are ye sad sir? how would this have grieved you,
If ye had fallen under a professed enemy?
Under one had taken vantage of your shame too?
Pray ye be at peace, I am so far from wronging ye,
Or glorying in the pride of such a victory,
That I desire to serve ye, pray look cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Do you hear this sir? this love sir? do you see this Gentleman
How he courts ye? why do you hold your head down?
It is no high treason I take it, to be equalled,
To have a slip in the field, no sin that is mortal;
Come, come, thank fortune and your friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It may be
You think my tongue may prove your enemy;
And though restrained sometimes, out of a bravery
May take a license to disable ye:
Believe me sir, so much I hate that liberty,
That in a strangers tongue it will prove an injury,
And I shall right you in it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Can you have more Uncle?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Sir you have beat me both ways, yet so nobly,
That I shall ever love the hand that did it:
Fortune may make me worthy of some title
That may be near your friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir I must leave ye,
But with so hearty love, and pray be confident,
I carry nothing from this place shall wrong ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come, come, you are right again, sir love your honour,
And love your friend, take heed of bloody purposes,
And unjust ends, good heaven is angry with him;
Make your fair vertues, and your fame your mistress,
And let these trinkets go.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You teach well nephew,
Now to be honourable even with this Gentleman,
Shall be my business, and my ends his.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Sir, sir, you must do something suddenly,
To stop his pride so great and high, he is shot up,
Upon his person too, your state is sunk else:
You must not stand now upon terms of gratitude,
And let a simple tenderness besot ye:
I will bring ye suddenly where you shall see him,
Attempting your brave sister privately;
Mark but his high behaviour then.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will Father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: And with scorn, I fear contempt too.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I will not name a lust;
It may be that also;
A little force must be applied upon him,
Now now applied, a little force to humble him.
These sweet entreaties do but make him wanton.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Take heed ye wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Take heed to your safety,
I but forewarn ye King; if you mistrust me,
Or think I come unsent --

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No I will go with you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Madam, you see there is nothing I can reach at,
Either in my obedience, or my service,
That May deserve your love, or win a liking,
But a poor thought, but I pursue it seriously,
Take pleasure in your wills, even in your anger,
Which other men would grudge at, and grow stormy;
I study new humility to please ye.
And take a kind of joy in my afflictions,
Because they come from ye, I love my sorrows:
Pray Madam but consider --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Yes, I do sir,
And to that honest end I drew ye hither;
I know ye have deserved as much as man can,
And know it is a justice to requite you:
I know ye love.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If ever love was mortal,
And dwelt in man, and for that love command me,
So strong I find it, and so true, here Lady,
Something of such a greatness to allow me,
Those things I have done already, may seem foils too:
It is equity that man aspires to heaven,
Should win it by his worth, and not sleep to it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now stand close King and hear, and as you find him,
Believe me right, or let religion suffer.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I dare believe your worth without additions;
But since you are so liberal of your love sir,
And would be farther tried, I do intend it,
Because you shall not, or you would not win me
At such an easy rate.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am prepared still,
And if I shrink --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I know ye are no coward,
This is the utmost trial of your constancy,
And if you stand fast now, I am yours, your wife sir;
You hold there is nothing dear that may achieve me,
Doubted or dangerous.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: There is nothing, nothing:
Let me but know, that I may straight fly to it.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I will tell you then, change your religion,
And be of one belief with me.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Mark,
Worship our Gods, renounce that faith you are bred in;
It is easily done, I will teach ye suddenly;
And humbly on your knees --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Ha? I will be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Offer as we do.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: To the Devil Lady?
Offer to him I hate? I know the devil,
To dogs and cuts? you make offer to them;
To every bird that flies, and every worm.
How terribly I shake? Is this the venture?
The trial that you talked off? where have I been?
And how forgot myself? how lost my memory?
When did I pray or look up steadfastly?
Had any goodness in my heart to guide me?
That I should give this vantage to mine enemy;
The enemy to my peace, forsake my faith.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Come, come, I know ye love me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love ye this way?
This most destroying way? sure you but jest Lady.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: My love and life are one way.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love alone then, and mine another way,
I will love diseases first,
Dote on a villain that would cut my throat,
Woo all afflictions of all sorts, kiss cruelty;
Have mercy heaven, how have I been wandering?
Wandering the way of lust, and left my maker?
How have I slept like Cork upon a water,
And had no feeling of the storm that tossed me?
Trod the blind paths of death? forsook assurance,
Eternity of blessedness for a woman?
For a young handsome face hazard my being?

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: Are not our powers eternal so their comforts?
As great and full of hopes as yours?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: They are puppets.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now mark him sir, and but observe him nearly,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Their comforts like themselves, cold senseless outsides;
You make them sick, as we are, peevish, mad,
Subject to age; and how can they cure us,
That are not able to refine themselves?

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: The Sun and Moon we worship, those are heavenly,
And their bright influences we believe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Away fool,
I adore the Maker of that Sun and Moon,
That gives those bodies light and influence,
That pointed out their paths, and taught their motions;
They are not so great as we, they are our servants,
Placed there to teach us time, to give us knowledge
Of when and how the swellings of the main air,
And their returns again; they are but our stewards
To make the earth fat with their influence,
That she may bring forth her increase and feed us.
Shall I fall from this faith to please a woman?
For her embraces bring my soul to ruin?
I looked you should have said, make me a Christian,
Work that great cure, for it is a great one woman;
That labour truly do perform, that venture
The crown of all great trial, and the fairest:
I looked ye should have wept and kneeled to beg it,
Washed off your mist of ignorance, with waters
Pure and repentant, from those eyes; I looked
You should have brought me your chief god ye worship,
He that you offer human blood and life to,
And made a sacrifice of him to memory,
Beat down his Altars, ruined his false Temples.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now you may see.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: Take heed, you go too far sir,
And yet I love to hear him; I must have ye,
And to that end I let you storm a little;
I know there must be some strife in your bosom
To cool and quiet ye, ere you can come back:
I know old friends cannot part suddenly,
There will be some let still, yet I must have ye,
Have ye of my faith too, and so enjoy ye.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Now I contemn ye, and I hate myself
For looking on that face lasciviously,
And it looks ugly now methinks.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: How Portugall?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It looks like death itself, to which it would lead me;
Your eyes resemble pale despair, they fright me,
And in their rounds a thousand horrid ruins,
Methinks I see; and in your tongue hear fearefully
The hideous murmurs of weak souls have suffered;
Get from me, I despise ye, and know woman,
That for all this trap you have laid to catch my life in,
To catch my immortal life, I hate and curse ye,
Contemn your deities, spurn at their powers,
And where I meet your mammet Gods, I will swing them
Thus over my head, and kick them into puddles,
Nay I will out of vengeance search your Temples,
And with those hearts that serve my God, demolish
Your shambles of wild worships.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now, now you hear sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I will have my faith since you are so crafty,
The glorious cross, although I love your brother;
Let him frown too, I will have my devotion,
And let your whole State storm.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Enter and take him;
I am sorry friend that I am forced to do this.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Be sure you bind him fast.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: But use him nobly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Had it to me been done, I had forgiven it,
And still preserved you fair, but to our Gods sir --

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Methinks I hate them now,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: To our Religion,
To these to be thus stubborn, thus rebellious
To threaten them.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Use all your violence,
I ask no mercy, nor repent my words;
I spit at your best powers; I serve one,
Will give me strength to scourge your gods.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: To grind them into base dust, and disperse them,
That never more their bloody memories --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Clap him close up.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Good friend be cooler.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Never;
Your painted sister I despise too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Softly.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: And all her devilish arts laugh and scorn at,
Mock her blind purposes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You must be temperate;
Offer him no violence I command you strictly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now thou art up I shall have time to speak too.

sp.speaker: Quis.
sp.l: O how I love this man, how truly honour him.

body.stage: Enter Christophero, and Pedro (at one doore) Emanuel. and Soza, (at another.)

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Do you know the news Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Would we knew as well sir
How to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Is this the love they bear us,
For our late benefit? taken so maliciously,
And clapped up close? is that the thanks they render?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: It must not be put up thus, smothered slightly,
It is such a base unnatural wrong.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know,
They may think to do wonders, aim at all,
And to blow us with a vengeance out of the Islands:
But if we be ourselves honest and resolute,
And continue but Masters of our ancient courages,
Stick close and give no vantage to their villainies --

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Nay if we faint or fall apieces now,
We are fools and worthy to be marked for misery;
Begin to strike at him they are all bound to?
To cancel his deserts? what must we look for
If they can carry this?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will carry coals then;
I have but one life, and one fortune Gentlemen,
But I will so husband it to vex these rascals,
These barbarous slaves.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Shall we go charge them presently?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: No that will be too weak, and too foolhardy,
We must have grounds that promise safety friends,
And sure offence, we lose our angers else,
And worse than that, venture our lives too lightly.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Did you see mine Uncle? plague on these Barbarians,
How the rogues stick in my teeth, I know ye are angry,
So I am too, monstrous angry Gentlemen,
I am angry that I choke again.
You hear Arusias up, honest Arm:
Clapped up in prison friends, the brave Arm:
Here are fine boys.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: We hope he shall not stay there.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Stay? no he must not stay, no talk of staying,
These are no times to stay; are not these Rascals?
Speake, I beseech ye speak, are they not Rogues?
Think some abominable names -- are they not Devils?
But the devil is a great deal too good for them -- fusty villains.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: They are a kind of hounds.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hounds were their fathers,
Old blear-eyed bob-tailed hounds -- Lord where is my Uncle?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: But what shall be done sir?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Done?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Yes to relieve him;
If it be not sudden they may take his life too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: They dare as soon take fire and swallow it,
Take stakes and thrust into their tails for glisters:
His life, why it is a thing worth all the Islands,
And they know will be rated at that value;
His very imprisonment will make the Town stink,
And shake and stink, I have physic in my hand for them
Shall give the goblins such a purge --

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I hear strange news, and have been seeking ye;
They say Armusia is prisoner.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It is most certain.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Upon what cause?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He has deserved too much sir;
The old heathen policy has light upon him,
And paid him home.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A most unnoble dealing.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You are the next if you can carry it tamely,
He has deserved of all.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I must confess it,
Of me so nobly too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I am glad to hear it,
You have a time now to make good your confession,
Your faith will show but cold else, and for fashion,
Now to redeem all, now to thank his courtesy,
Now to make those believe that held you backward,
And an ill instrument, you are a Gentleman,
An honest man, and you dare love your Nation,
Dare stick to virtue though she be oppressed,
And for her own fair sake step to her Rescue:
If you live ages sir, and lose this hour,
Not now redeem, and vindicate your honour,
Your life will be a murmur, and no man in it.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I thank ye nephew, come along with me Gentlemen,
We will make them dancing sport immediately:
We are Masters of the Port yet, we shall see
What that can do.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Let it but spit fire finely,
And play their turrets, and their painted Palaces,
A frisking round or two, that they may trip it,
And caper in the air.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Come, we will do something
Shall make them look about, we will send them plums
If they be not too hard for their teeth.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And fine Potatoes
Roasted in gunpowder, such a banquet sir
Will prepare their unmannerly stomachs.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: They shall see
There is no safe retreat in villainy;
Come be high hearted all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are all on fire sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am ungrateful, and a wretch, persuade me not,
Forgetful of the mercy he showed me,
The timely noble pity -- why should I
See him fast bound and fettered, whose true courtesy,
Whose manhood, and whose mighty hand set me free?
Why should it come from me? why I command this?
Shall not all tongues and truths call me unthankful?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Had the offence been thrown on you, it is certain
It had been in your power, and your discretion
To have turned it into mercy, and forgiven it,
And then it had showed a virtuous point of gratitude,
Timely and nobly taken; but since the cause
Concerns the honour of our gods, and their title,
And so transcends your power, and your compassion,
A little your own safety if you saw it too,
If your too fond indulgence did not dazzle you,
It cannot now admit a private pity;
It is in their wills, their mercies, or revenges,
And these revolts in you show mere rebellious.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: They are mild and pitiful.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To those repent.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Their nature is soft and tender.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To true hearts
That feele compunction for their trespasses:
This man defies them still, threatens destruction
And demolition of their arms and worship,
Spits at their powers; take heed ye be not found sir,
And marked a favourer of their dishonour;
They use no common justice.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What shall I do
To deserve of this man --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: If ye more bemoan him,
Or mitigate your power to preserve him,
I will curse ye from the gods, call up their vengeance,
sp.stage: Enter Quisara with her hands bound, Quisana; Panura.
sp.l: And fling it on your Land and you, I have charge for it;
I hope to wrack you all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What ails my sister?
Why is she bound? why looks she so distractedly?
Who does do this?

sp.speaker: Quisan.
sp.l: We did it, pardon sir,
And for her preservation -- She is grown wild,
And raving on the strangers love and honour,
Sometimes crying out, help, help, they will torture him,
They will take his life, they will murder him, presently,
If we had not prevented, violently
Have laid hands on her own life.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These are tokens
The gods displeasure is gone out, be quick,
And ere it fall do something to appease them,
You know the sacrifice -- I am glad it works thus.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: How low and base thou lookest now that wert noble?
No figure of a King methinks shows on you,
No face of Majesty, foul swarthy ingratitude
Has taken off thy sweetness, base forgetfulness
Of mighty benefits, has turned thee Devil:
Thou hast persecuted goodness, innocence,
And laid a hard and violent hand on virtue,
On that fair virtue that should teach and guide us;
Thou hast wronged thine own preserver, whose least merit
Poised with thy main estate, thou canst not satisfy,
Nay put thy life in too, it will be too light still:
What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Go for him presently,
And once more we will try if we can win him fairly:
If not, let nothing she says hinder ye, or stir ye;
She speaks distractedly -- Do that the gods command ye:
Do you know what ye say Lady?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: I could curse thee too,
Religion and severity has steeled thee,
Has turned thy heart to stone; thou hast made the gods hard too,
Against their sweet and patient natures, cruel:
None of ye feele what bravery ye tread on?
What innocence? what beauty?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Pray be patient.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: What honourable things ye cast behind ye?
What monuments of man?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Once more Armusia,
Because I love ye tenderly and dearly,
And would be glad to win ye mine, I wish ye,
Even from my heart I wish and woo ye --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What sir,
Take heed how ye persuade me falsely, then ye hate me;
Take heed how ye entrap me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I advise ye,
And tenderly and truly I advise ye,
Both for your souls health and your safety.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stay,
And name my soul no more, she is too precious,
Too glorious for your flatteries, too secure too.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Consider the reward sir, and the honour
That is prepared, the glory you shall grow to.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: They are not to be considered in these cases,
Not to be named when souls are questioned;
They are vain and flying vapours -- touch my life,
It is ready for ye, put it to what test
It shall please ye, I am patient; but for the rest
You may remove rocks with your little fingers,
Or blow a mountain out of the way, with bellows,
As soon as stir my faith; use no more arguments.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: We must use tortures then.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Your worst and painfullest
I am joyful to accept.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You must the sharpest,
For such has been your hate against our deities
Delivered openly, your threats and scornings,
And either your repentance must be mighty,
Which is your free conversion to our customs,
Or equal punishment, which is your life sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am glad I have it for ye, take it Priest,
And all the miseries that shall attend it:
Let the Gods glut themselves with Christian blood,
It will be asked again, and so far followed,
So far revenged, and with such holy justice,
Your Gods of gold shall melt and sink before it;
Your Altars, and your Temples shake to nothing;
And you false worshippers, blind fools of ceremony,
Shall seek for, holes to hide your heads, and fears in,
For seas to swallow you from this destruction,
Darkness to dwell about ye, and conceal ye,
Your mothers wombs again --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Make the fires ready,
And bring the several tortures out.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Stand fast sir,
And fear them not, you that have stepped so nobly
Into this pious trial start not now,
Keep on your way, a virgin will assist ye,
A virgin won by your fair constancy,
And glorying that she is won so, will die by ye;
I have touched ye every way, tried ye most honest,
Perfect, and good, chaste, blushing chaste, and temperate,
Valiant, without vain glory, modest, stayed,
No rage, or light affection ruling in you:
Indeed, the perfect school of worth I find ye,
The temple of true honour.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Whether will she?
What do you infer by this fair argument Lady?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Your faith, and your religion must be like ye,
They that can show you these, must be pure mirrors,
When the streams flow clear and fair, what are the fountains?
I do embrace your faith sir, and your fortune;
Go on , I will assist ye, I feele a sparkle here,
A lively spark that kindles my affection,
And tells me it will rise to flames of glory:
Let them put on their angers, suffer nobly,
Show me the way, and when I faint instruct me;
And if I follow not --

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: O blessed Lady,
Since thou art won, let me begin my triumph,
Come clap your terrors on.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: All your fell tortures.
For there is nothing he shall suffer brother,
I swear by new faith which is most sacred,
And I will keep it so but I will follow in,
And follow to a scruple of affliction,
In spite of all your Gods without prevention.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Death she amazes me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What shall be done now?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They must die both,
And suddenly, they will corrupt all else;
This woman makes me weary of my mischief,
She shakes me, and she staggers me, go in sir,
I will see the execution.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not so sudden:
If they go all my friends and sisters perish.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Would I were safe at home again .

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Arm, arm sir,
Seek for defence, the Castle plays and thunders,
The Town Rocks, and the houses fly in the air,
The people die for fear -- Captain Ruy Dias,
Has made an Oath he will not leave a stone here;
No not the memory, here has stood a City,
Unless Armusia be delivered fairly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I have my fears: what can our gods do now for us?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Be patient, But keep him still: he is a cure sir
Against both rage and Cannon: go and fortify,
Call in the Princess, make the Palace sure,
And let them know you are a King: look nobly;
And take your courage to ye; keep close the prisoner,
And under command, we are betrayed else.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How joyfully I go?

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Take my heart with thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I hold a Wolf by the ear now:
Fortune free me.
Heaven bless us,
What a thundering is here? what fire-spitting?
We cannot drink, but our Cans are mauled amongst us.
I would they would mall our scores too:
Shame on their Guns, I thought they had been bird-pots,
Or great Candlecases, how devilishly they bounce.
And how the Bullets borrow a piece of a house here,
There another, and mend those up again.
With another parish; here flies a powdering-tub,
The meat ready roasted and there a barrel pissing vinegar,
And they two over-taking the top of a high Steeple,
Newly sliced off for a sallet.
A vengeance fire them.
Nay they fire fast enough;
You need not help them.
Are these the Bulls Portugall --
How loud they bellow?
Their horns are plaguey strong, they push down Palaces
They toss our little habitations like whelps,
Like grindle-tails, with their heels upward;
All the windows in the town dance a new trench-more,
It is like to prove a blessed age for Glasiers,
I met a hand, and a Letter in it in great haste,
And by and by a single leg running after it,
As if the Arm had forgot part of his arrant,
Heads fly like foot-balls everywhere .
What shall we do?
I care not, my shop is cancelled,
And all the Pots and earthen pans in it vanished:
There was a single Bullet and they together by the ears;
You would have thought Tom Tumbler had been there,
And all his troop of devils.
Let us to the King,
And get this gentleman delivered handsomely;
By this hand there is no walking above ground else.
By this leg -- Let me swear nimbly by it,
For I know not how long I shall owe it,
If I were out of the Town once, if I came in again to
Fetch my breakfast, I will give them leave to cram me
With a Portugall pudding: Come,let us do anything
To appease this thunder,

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Art sure it was that blind priest?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes most certain,
He has provoked all this; the King is merciful,
And wondrous loving; but he fires him on still,
And when he cools enrages him, I know it,
Threatens new vengeance, and the gods fierce justice
When he but looks with fair eyes on Armusia,
Will lend him no time to relent; my royal Mistress,
She has entertained a Christian hope.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Speake truly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nay it is most true, but Lord, how he lies at her,
And threatens her, and flatters her, and dams her,
And I fear, if not speedily prevented,
If she continue stout, both shall be executed.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I will kiss thee for this news: nay more Panura,
If thou wilt give me leave, I will get thee with Christian,
The best way to convert thee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Make me believe so.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I will i'faith. But which way camest thou hither?
The Palace is close guarded, and barricadoed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I came through a private vault, which few there know of;
It rises in a Temple not far hence,
Close by the Castle here.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How -- To what end?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: A good one:
To give ye knowledge of my new-born Mistress,
And in what doubt Armusia stands,
Think any present means, or hope to stop them
From their fell ends: the Princes are come in too,
And they are hardened also.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: The damned Priest --

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sure he is a cruel man, methinks Religion
Should teach more temperate lessons.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He the fire-brand?
He dare to touch at such fair lives as theirs are?
Well Prophet, I shall prophecy, I shall catch ye,
When all your Prophecies will not redeem ye?
Wilt thou do one thing bravely?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Any good I am able.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And by thine own white hand I will swear thou art virtuous,
And a brave wench, durst thou but guide me presently
Through the same vault thou camest into the Palace,
And those I shall appoint, such as I think sit.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Yes, I will do it, and suddenly, and truly.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I would fain behold this Prophet.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Now I have ye;
And shall bring ye where ye shall behold him,
Alone too, and unfurnished of defences:
That shall be my care; but you must not betray me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Dost thou think we are so base? such slaves, rogues?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I do not:
And you shall see how fairly I will work for ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I must needs steal that Priest,
Steal him, and hang him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Do anything to remove his mischief, strangle him --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come prithee love.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You will offer me no foul play?
The Vault is dark.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It was well remembered.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And ye may --
But I hold ye honest.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Honest enough, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I am but a poor weak wench; and what with the place.
And your persuasions Sir -- but I hope you will not;
You know we are often cozened.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: If thou dost fear me,
Why dost thou put me in mind?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: To let you know sir,
Though it be in your power, and things sitting to it,
Yet a true gentleman --

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I know what he will do:
Come and remember me, and I will answer thee,
And then my good guide do thy will; shalt find me
A very tractable man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I hope I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Bak.
sp.l: Let my men guard the gates.

sp.speaker: Syan.
sp.l: And mine the Temple,
For fear the honour of our gods should suffer,
And on your lives be watchful.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And be valiant;
And let us see, if these Portugalls dare enter;
What their high hearts dare do: Let us see how readily,
The great Ruy Dias will redeem his Countrymen;
He speaks proud words, and threatens.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He is approved sir,
And will put fair for what he promises;
I could wish friendlier terms,
Yet for our Liberties, and for our gods,
We are bound in our best service
Even in the hazard of our lives.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Come up Princes,
And give your counsels, and your helps, the Fort still
Plays fearfully upon us, beats our buildings,
And turns our people wild with fears.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Send for the prisoner,
And give us leave to argue.

body.stage: Exit Ba.and Sy.Then, Enter Ruy Dyas, Emanuel, Christoph, Pedro, with Sould.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Come on nobly,
And let the Fort play still, we are
Strong enough to look upon them,
And return at pleasure; it may
Be on our view they will return him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: We will return them such thanks else,
Shall make them scratch where it itches not.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How the people stare,
And some cry, some pray, and some curse heartily:
But it is the King --

body.stage: Enter Syana, Bakam, Quisara, Armusia, with Souldiers above.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I cannot blame their wisdoms,
They are all above, Armusia chained and bound too?
O these are thankful Squires.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Hear us Ruy Dias,
Be wise and hear us, and give speedy answer,
Command thy Cannon presently to cease,
No more to trouble the afflicted People,
Or suddenly Armusias head goes off,
As suddenly as said.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Stay Sir, be moderate.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Do nothing that is dishonourable Ruy Dyas,
Let not the fear of me master thy valour;
Pursue them still, they are base malicious people.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Friend be not desperate.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I scorn your courtesies;
Strike when you dare, a fair arm guide the Gunner,
And may he let fly still with fortune: friend,
Do me the honour of a soldiers funerals,
The last fair Christian right, see me in the ground,
And let the palace burn first, then the Temples,
And on their scorned gods erect my monument:
Touch not the Princess, as you are a soldier.

sp.speaker: Quisar.
sp.l: Which way you go, sir,
I must follow necessary.
One life, and one death.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will you take a truce yet?

body.stage: Enter Pyniero, Soza, and Souldiers with the Governour.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: No, no, go on:
Look here your god, your Prophet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How came he taken?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I Conjured for him King.
I am sure Cur at an old blind Prophet.
I will haunt ye such a false knave admirably,
A terrier I; I earthed him, and then snapped him;

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Saving the reverence of your grace, we stole him
Even out of the next chamber to ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come, come, begin King,
Begin this bloody matter when you dare;
And yet I scorn my sword should touch the rascal,
I will tear him thus before ye. Ha!
What art thou?

body.stage: Pulls his Beard and haire off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How is this!
Art thou a Prophet?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Come down Princes.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We are abused --
O my most dear Armusia --
Off which his chains. And now my noble sister,
Rejoice with me, I know ye are pleased as I am.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is a precious Prophet. Why Don Governor,
What make you here? how long have you taken orders?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Why what a wretch
Art thou to work this mischief?
To assume this holy shape to ruin honour,
Honour and chastity?

body.stage: Enter King, and all from above.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I had paid you all,
But fortune played the slut. Come,
Give me my doom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot speak for wonder.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Nay, it is I sir,
And here I stay your sentence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take her friend,
You have half persuaded me to be a Christian,
And with her all the joys, and all the blessings.
Why what dream have we dwelt in?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: All peace to ye,
And all the happiness of heart dwell with ye,
Children as sweet and noble as their Parents.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And Kings at least.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good Sir forget my rashness.
And noble Princess, for I was once angry,
And out of that might utter some distemper,
Think not it is my nature.

sp.speaker: Sya.
sp.l: Your joy is ours sir,
And nothing we find in ye, But most noble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To prison with this dog, there let him howl,
And if he can repent, sigh out his villainies:
His Island we shall seize into our hands,
His father and himself have both usurped it,
And kept it by oppression; the Town and Castle,
In which I lay myself most miserable,
Till my most honourable friend redeemed me,
Seignior Pyniero I bestow on you,
The rest of next command upon these gentlemen,
Upon ye all my love.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: O brave Ruy Dias.
You have started now beyond me. I must thank ye,
And thank ye for my life, my wife and honour.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I am glad I had her for you sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Princes,
Come friends and lovers all, come noble gentlemen,
No more guns now, nor hates but joys and triumphs,
An universal gladness fly about us:
And know however subtle men dare cast,
And promise wrack, the gods give peace at last.
